Overview

NeutroHydro implements a mathematically well-posed workflow for groundwater chemometrics in absolute concentration space (non-compositional):

Raw Ion Data
     ↓
Preprocessing (Robust centering/scaling)
     ↓
NDG Encoder (T, I, F triplets)
     ↓
PNPLS Regression (Augmented Hilbert space)
     ↓
NVIP (Channel-wise variable importance)
     ↓
NSR/π_G (Baseline vs perturbation attribution)
     ↓
Mineral Inference (Stoichiometric inversion)

Core Mathematical Innovations

1. Neutrosophic Data Representation

Maps each ion concentration to a triplet (T, I, F):

  • T (Truth): Baseline/reference component
  • I (Indeterminacy): Uncertainty/ambiguity
  • F (Falsity): Perturbation likelihood

2. L2-Additive VIP Decomposition

Theorem: Variable importance decomposes additively across channels:

VIPagg2(j)=VIPT2(j)+VIPI2(j)+VIPF2(j)VIP_{agg}^2(j) = VIP_T^2(j) + VIP_I^2(j) + VIP_F^2(j)VIPagg2​(j)=VIPT2​(j)+VIPI2​(j)+VIPF2​(j)

This allows unambiguous attribution of prediction importance to baseline vs. perturbation sources.

3. Non-Compositional Framework

Unlike compositional data analysis (CoDa), NeutroHydro operates in absolute concentration space, preserving:

  • Physical interpretability
  • Additive mixing models
  • Direct stoichiometric constraints

4. Hybrid Geochemical-Statistical Engine

Combines rigorous mathematical optimization with expert hydrogeochemical heuristics:

  • Context-Aware Inversion: Uses WHO Quality Flags and Gibbs Diagrams to dynamically constrain the mineral solver.
  • Redox Detection: Explicitly solves for mass loss (e.g., Denitrification) using negative stoichiometry.
  • Advanced Indices: Integrated Simpson's Ratio (Standard & Inverse) for precise salinity diagnosis (Seawater vs. Recharge).

Quick Start Guide

This guide will help you run your first analysis using NeutroHydro.

1. Basic Workflow

The core of NeutroHydro is the NeutroHydroPipeline. It handles preprocessing, encoding, model training, and mineral inversion in a single step.

Step 1: Prepare Your Data

Prepare a CSV file (e.g., data.csv) with your ion concentrations. The columns should match standard chemical symbols (e.g., Ca, Mg, Na, HCO3, Cl, SO4).

SampleID Ca Mg Na K HCO3 Cl SO4 NO3
S1 45 12 25 3 150 30 40 5
S2 80 25 60 5 200 85 90 12

Step 2: Run the Pipeline

Create a Python script (e.g., analysis.py):

import pandas as pd
from neutrohydro import NeutroHydroPipeline

# 1. Load Data
df = pd.read_csv("data.csv")

# 2. Initialize Pipeline
# 'target_ions' are the ions you want to model/predict (usually all major ions)
pipeline = NeutroHydroPipeline(
    target_ions=["Ca", "Mg", "Na", "K", "HCO3", "Cl", "SO4", "NO3"]
)

# 3. Fit the Model
# The pipeline automatically handles preprocessing and encoding
pipeline.fit(df)

# 4. Get Results
# This returns a dictionary containing all analysis outputs
results = pipeline.analyze(df)

# 5. Access Specific Outputs
print("Variable Importance (VIP):")
print(results["vip_scores"])

print("\nMineral Contributions (First Sample):")
print(results["mineral_fractions"].iloc[0])

print("\nWater Quality Flags:")
print(results["quality_flags"].iloc[0])

2. Advanced Features

Mineral Inversion with Quality Constraints

NeutroHydro can use water quality flags (like WHO exceedances) to constrain the mineral inversion.

# The pipeline does this automatically if you use the .analyze() method.
# You can access the quality assessment directly:

quality_df = results["quality_flags"]
print(quality_df[["Exceedances", "Inferred_Sources"]].head())

Hydrogeochemical Indices

The analysis also calculates standard indices automatically:

indices = results["indices"]
print(indices[["Simpson_Class", "Simpson_Ratio_Inverse", "Gibbs_Ratio_1"]].head())

3. Visualization

You can quickly visualize the results using standard libraries.

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Plot Mineral Fractions for the first 5 samples
minerals = results["mineral_fractions"].head(5)
minerals.plot(kind="bar", stacked=True)
plt.title("Mineral Composition")
plt.ylabel("Fraction")
plt.show()

Next Steps

  • Learn about the Mathematical Framework.
  • Explore Mineral Inversion details.
  • Check the API Reference for full documentation.

Installation Guide

Prerequisites

  • Python 3.9 or higher
  • pip (Python package installer)

Installation from Source

NeutroHydro is currently available as a source distribution. To install it, clone the repository and install using pip.

  1. Clone the repository:

    git clone https://github.com/yourusername/neutrohydro.git
cd neutrohydro

  2. Create a virtual environment (Recommended):

    # Windows
python -m venv .venv
.venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1

# Linux/macOS
python3 -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate

  3. Install the package:

    pip install .

    For development (including testing and documentation tools):

    pip install -e .[dev]

Verifying Installation

To verify that NeutroHydro is installed correctly, you can run the following command in your terminal:

python -c "import neutrohydro; print(neutrohydro.__version__)"

If installed correctly, this should print the version number without errors.

Dependencies

The core dependencies are automatically installed:

  • numpy
  • pandas
  • scikit-learn
  • scipy
  • matplotlib (for plotting)
  • seaborn (for advanced visualization)

Mathematical Framework Overview

1. Introduction

NeutroHydro implements a neutrosophic chemometric framework for groundwater analysis that operates in absolute concentration space. This document provides a high-level overview of the mathematical theory underpinning the package.

2. Problem Statement

2.1 Input Data

  • Predictor matrix: X∈Rn×pX \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}X∈Rn×p, where:

    • nnn = number of water samples
    • ppp = number of ion species (e.g., Ca²⁺, Mg²⁺, Na⁺, Cl⁻, etc.)
    • XijX_{ij}Xij​ = concentration of ion jjj in sample iii (units: mg/L, meq/L, etc.)

  • Target vector: y∈Rny \in \mathbb{R}^ny∈Rn

    • Typically: log TDS, log EC, or log ionic strength
    • Scalar response for each sample

2.2 Objectives

  1. Predict target yyy from ion concentrations XXX
  2. Decompose prediction importance into:
    • Baseline/reference component (geogenic/natural)
    • Perturbation component (anthropogenic/anomalous)
  3. Infer plausible mineral sources via stoichiometry

3. Workflow Overview 

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ PHASE 1: PREPROCESSING (Section 2)                         │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│ Input:  X, y (raw concentrations)                          │
│ Output: X_std, y_std (standardized)                        │
│                                                             │
│ Operations:                                                 │
│ • Optional log transform: X_log = log(X + δ_x)            │
│ • Robust centering: μ_j = median(X_j)                      │
│ • Robust scaling: s_j = 1.4826 × MAD(X_j)                 │
│ • Standardize: X_std = (X - μ) / (s + δ_s)                │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
                            ↓
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ PHASE 2: NDG ENCODING (Section 3)                          │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│ Input:  X_std                                               │
│ Output: Triplets (X_T, X_I, X_F)                          │
│                                                             │
│ Truth Channel (T):                                          │
│   X_T = B(X_std)    [baseline operator]                   │
│                                                             │
│ Residuals:                                                  │
│   R = X_std - X_T                                          │
│   σ_j = 1.4826 × MAD(R_j)                                 │
│                                                             │
│ Falsity Channel (F):                                        │
│   u_ij = |R_ij| / σ_j                                      │
│   F_ij = 1 - exp(-u_ij)    [perturbation likelihood]      │
│                                                             │
│ Indeterminacy Channel (I):                                 │
│   I_ij ∈ [0,1]    [uncertainty/ambiguity]                 │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
                            ↓
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ PHASE 3: PNPLS REGRESSION (Section 4)                      │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│ Input:  Triplets (X_T, X_I, X_F), y_std                   │
│ Output: PLS components (T, W, P, q, β)                    │
│                                                             │
│ Augmented Space:                                            │
│   X_aug = [X_T  √ρ_I·X_I  √ρ_F·X_F] ∈ ℝ^(n×3p)          │
│                                                             │
│ Precision Weights:                                          │
│   W_ij = exp(-λ_F · F_ij)                                  │
│   X̃_aug = W ⊙ X_aug    [elementwise product]             │
│                                                             │
│ PLS Decomposition (NIPALS):                                │
│   Extract k latent components                               │
│   Prediction: ŷ = X̃_aug · β                               │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
                            ↓
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ PHASE 4: NVIP DECOMPOSITION (Section 5)                    │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│ Input:  PLS weights W, scores T, loadings q                │
│ Output: VIP_T, VIP_I, VIP_F, VIP_agg                      │
│                                                             │
│ Channel Energies:                                           │
│   E_T(j) = VIP_T²(j)                                       │
│   E_I(j) = VIP_I²(j)                                       │
│   E_F(j) = VIP_F²(j)                                       │
│                                                             │
│ L2 Decomposition Theorem:                                   │
│   VIP_agg²(j) = VIP_T²(j) + VIP_I²(j) + VIP_F²(j)        │
│                                                             │
│ Interpretation:                                             │
│   VIP_agg(j) ≥ 1  ⟹  ion j is important for prediction  │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
                            ↓
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ PHASE 5: ATTRIBUTION (Sections 6-7)                        │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│ Input:  NVIP energies, regression coefficients             │
│ Output: NSR, π_G (ion-level), G_i (sample-level)          │
│                                                             │
│ Ion-Level Attribution:                                      │
│   E_P(j) = E_I(j) + E_F(j)    [perturbation energy]       │
│   π_G(j) = E_T(j) / [E_T(j) + E_P(j)]    ∈ [0,1]         │
│   NSR(j) = E_T(j) / E_P(j)    [odds ratio]                │
│                                                             │
│ Classification (threshold γ = 0.7):                         │
│   π_G(j) ≥ γ       ⟹  baseline-dominant                  │
│   π_G(j) ≤ 1-γ     ⟹  perturbation-dominant              │
│   otherwise        ⟹  mixed                                │
│                                                             │
│ Sample-Level Attribution:                                   │
│   w_ij = |contribution of ion j in sample i|              │
│   G_i = Σ_j π_G(j)·w_ij / Σ_j w_ij    ∈ [0,1]           │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
                            ↓
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ PHASE 6: MINERAL INFERENCE (Section 8) [Optional]          │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│ Input:  Ion concentrations c (meq/L), π_G                  │
│ Output: Mineral contributions s, plausibility              │
│                                                             │
│ Stoichiometric Model:                                       │
│   c ≈ A·s    where s ≥ 0                                   │
│   A ∈ ℝ^(m×K): stoichiometric matrix                      │
│   s ∈ ℝ^K: mineral contributions                          │
│                                                             │
│ Weighted NNLS:                                              │
│   D = diag(π_G(1)^η, ..., π_G(m)^η)                       │
│   ŝ = argmin_{s≥0} ‖D(c - As)‖²                           │
│                                                             │
│ Plausibility Criteria:                                      │
│   Mineral k plausible if:                                   │
│     • ŝ_k > τ_s    (sufficient contribution)               │
│     • ‖D(c - Aŝ)‖ ≤ τ_r    (good fit)                     │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

4. Key Mathematical Guarantees

4.1 Euclidean Structure

All operations occur in true Euclidean spaces:

  • Preprocessing: Rp\mathbb{R}^pRp
  • Augmented space: R3p\mathbb{R}^{3p}R3p with inner product
    ⟨u,v⟩N=uT⊤vT+ρIuI⊤vI+ρFuF⊤vF\langle u, v \rangle_{\mathcal{N}} = u_T^\top v_T + \rho_I u_I^\top v_I + \rho_F u_F^\top v_F⟨u,v⟩N​=uT⊤​vT​+ρI​uI⊤​vI​+ρF​uF⊤​vF​
  • Well-defined projections, deflations, and orthogonality

4.2 L2 Additivity (Core Theorem)

Theorem (NVIP L2 Decomposition):

For each variable jjj:
VIPagg2(j)=VIPT2(j)+VIPI2(j)+VIPF2(j)VIP_{agg}^2(j) = VIP_T^2(j) + VIP_I^2(j) + VIP_F^2(j)VIPagg2​(j)=VIPT2​(j)+VIPI2​(j)+VIPF2​(j)

Proof Sketch:
The augmented weight vector for component hhh is:
wh=[wT,h⊤wI,h⊤wF,h⊤]⊤w_h = [w_{T,h}^\top \quad w_{I,h}^\top \quad w_{F,h}^\top]^\topwh​=[wT,h⊤​wI,h⊤​wF,h⊤​]⊤

VIP is computed as:
VIPc2(j)=p⋅∑h=1kSSYh⋅ωc,h(j)Ωh∑h=1kSSYhVIP_c^2(j) = p \cdot \frac{\sum_{h=1}^k SSY_h \cdot \frac{\omega_{c,h}(j)}{\Omega_h}}{\sum_{h=1}^k SSY_h}VIPc2​(j)=p⋅∑h=1k​SSYh​∑h=1k​SSYh​⋅Ωh​ωc,h​(j)​​

where ωc,h(j)=wc,h2(j)\omega_{c,h}(j) = w_{c,h}^2(j)ωc,h​(j)=wc,h2​(j) and Ωh=∥wh∥2\Omega_h = \|w_h\|^2Ωh​=∥wh​∥2.

Since Ωh=∑m[ωT,h(m)+ωI,h(m)+ωF,h(m)]\Omega_h = \sum_m [\omega_{T,h}(m) + \omega_{I,h}(m) + \omega_{F,h}(m)]Ωh​=∑m​[ωT,h​(m)+ωI,h​(m)+ωF,h​(m)], the normalized weights sum additively, yielding the L2 decomposition. □

4.3 Conservation Laws

Unity constraints:

  1. πG(j)+πA(j)=1\pi_G(j) + \pi_A(j) = 1πG​(j)+πA​(j)=1 for all ions jjj
  2. Gi+Ai=1G_i + A_i = 1Gi​+Ai​=1 for all samples iii

Bounds:

  1. VIPc(j)≥0VIP_c(j) \geq 0VIPc​(j)≥0 for all channels c∈{T,I,F}c \in \{T, I, F\}c∈{T,I,F}
  2. πG(j),Gi∈[0,1]\pi_G(j), G_i \in [0, 1]πG​(j),Gi​∈[0,1]
  3. Iij,Fij∈[0,1]I_{ij}, F_{ij} \in [0, 1]Iij​,Fij​∈[0,1]

4.4 Stability

  • Robust statistics: Median and MAD resist outliers
  • Precision weighting: High-falsity observations downweighted
  • Regularization: Optional ridge/elastic net in PLS

5. Operational vs. Causal Interpretation

5.1 Operational Definitions

The framework defines baseline and perturbation operationally:

  • Baseline = component captured by B(X(std))\mathcal{B}(X^{(std)})B(X(std))

    • Median ⟹ central tendency
    • Low-rank ⟹ common geochemical manifold
    • Robust PCA ⟹ low-rank + sparse decomposition

  • Perturbation = deviations from baseline, quantified by falsity FFF

5.2 External Validation Required

Attribution to physical sources (geogenic vs. anthropogenic) requires external evidence:

  • Spatial patterns (urban vs. rural)
  • Temporal trends (pre/post contamination event)
  • Isotopic tracers
  • Land use correlations

The framework provides consistent mathematical attribution; causal interpretation depends on domain knowledge.

6. Comparison to Other Methods

Feature NeutroHydro Standard PLS CoDa Methods
Space Absolute concentrations Absolute/relative Compositional (simplex)
VIP decomposition L2-additive (T, I, F) Single VIP Not applicable
Uncertainty Explicit (I channel) Implicit Not standard
Robustness Falsity weighting Optional Depends on method
Missing data EM imputation Varies Special handling
Stoichiometry Direct (NNLS) Post-hoc Difficult
Interpretability High (3 channels) Moderate Low (log-ratios)

7. Computational Complexity

Operation Complexity Notes
Preprocessing O(np)O(np)O(np) Median/MAD per column
NDG Encoding (median) O(np)O(np)O(np) Per-column operations
NDG Encoding (low-rank) O(npmin⁡(n,p))O(np \min(n,p))O(npmin(n,p)) SVD cost
PNPLS (k components) O(knp2)O(knp^2)O(knp2) NIPALS iterations
NVIP O(kp)O(kp)O(kp) Post-PLS computation
Attribution O(np)O(np)O(np) Linear pass
Mineral NNLS (per sample) O(m2K)O(m^2 K)O(m2K) Per-sample inversion

Total pipeline: O(knp2+nm2K)O(knp^2 + nm^2K)O(knp2+nm2K) where typically k≪n,pk \ll n, pk≪n,p and m,K≲10m, K \lesssim 10m,K≲10.

8. Hyperparameter Selection

8.1 Critical Parameters

  1. Number of components kkk:

    • Cross-validation (minimize RMSE on held-out data)
    • Elbow method (explained variance)
    • Typical range: 3–10

  2. Baseline type:

    • median: Fast, robust, interpretable (default)
    • low_rank: Captures geochemical manifold
    • robust_pca: Handles sparse anomalies

  3. Channel weights ρI,ρF\rho_I, \rho_FρI​,ρF​:

    • Default: ρI=ρF=1\rho_I = \rho_F = 1ρI​=ρF​=1 (equal)
    • Increase ρI\rho_IρI​ to emphasize uncertainty
    • Increase ρF\rho_FρF​ to emphasize perturbations

  4. Falsity strength λF\lambda_FλF​:

    • Default: λF=1\lambda_F = 1λF​=1
    • Higher values ⟹ stronger downweighting of anomalies
    • Typical range: 0.5–5

  5. Classification threshold γ\gammaγ:

    • Default: γ=0.7\gamma = 0.7γ=0.7
    • Higher γ\gammaγ ⟹ stricter baseline classification
    • Typical range: 0.6–0.8

8.2 Sensitivity Analysis

Recommended workflow:

  1. Fit with default hyperparameters
  2. Compute predictions and VIPs
  3. Vary one hyperparameter at a time
  4. Check stability of:
    • Top-ranked ions (VIP)
    • Classification (baseline vs. perturbation)
    • Prediction accuracy (R2R^2R2)

9. Limitations and Assumptions

9.1 Assumptions

  1. Linearity: PLS assumes (approximately) linear relationships
    • Mitigated by: log transforms, polynomial features
  2. Stationarity: Baseline operator assumes some regularity
    • Mitigated by: hydrofacies conditioning, spatial stratification
  3. Independence: Samples assumed independent
    • May violate: temporal autocorrelation, spatial clustering

9.2 Limitations

  1. Scalar response: Current implementation supports single target
    • Extension to multivariate YYY possible (PLS2/NPLS)
  2. Stoichiometry: Mineral inference assumes simple dissolution
    • Does not model: ion exchange, redox, precipitation, kinetics
  3. Computational: Large n,pn, pn,p may be slow
    • Mitigations: use baseline_type='median', reduce kkk

10. Software Implementation

The mathematical framework is implemented in Python with:

  • NumPy/SciPy: Core numerical operations
  • scikit-learn: PLS utilities (validation, not direct use)
  • Custom NIPALS: Channel-aware PLS implementation
  • SciPy.optimize.nnls: Non-negative least squares for minerals

All operations preserve numerical stability via:

  • Robust scaling (MAD, not std)
  • Small δ\deltaδ constants for division safety
  • SVD for pseudo-inverses
  • Convergence tolerances in iterative methods

Next: See individual module documentation for detailed equations and algorithms.

NDG Encoder: Neutrosophic Triplets

Module: neutrohydro.encoder

Overview

The NDG (Neutrosophic Data Generator) Encoder maps each standardized ion concentration to a neutrosophic triplet (T,I,F)(T, I, F)(T,I,F):

  • T (Truth): Baseline/reference component
  • I (Indeterminacy): Uncertainty/ambiguity
  • F (Falsity): Perturbation/anomaly likelihood

This representation enables explicit decomposition of prediction importance into baseline and perturbation sources.

Mathematical Foundation

1. Input

Standardized predictor matrix from preprocessing:
X(std)∈Rn×pX^{(\text{std})} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}X(std)∈Rn×p

2. Output

Three channel matrices:
XT,XI,XF∈Rn×pX_T, X_I, X_F \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}XT​,XI​,XF​∈Rn×p

Plus residuals and metadata:
R∈Rn×p,σ∈RpR \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}, \quad \sigma \in \mathbb{R}^pR∈Rn×p,σ∈Rp

Truth Channel (T): Baseline Operator

1. Definition

XT=B(X(std))X_T = \mathcal{B}(X^{(\text{std})})XT​=B(X(std))

where B:Rn×p→Rn×p\mathcal{B}: \mathbb{R}^{n \times p} \to \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}B:Rn×p→Rn×p is a baseline operator.

2. Baseline Operator Options

Option 1: Robust Columnwise Median (Default)

(XT)ij=mediani′(Xi′j(std))(X_T)_{ij} = \text{median}_{i'}(X^{(\text{std})}_{i'j})(XT​)ij​=mediani′​(Xi′j(std)​)

Replicated per row - constant baseline for each ion.

Advantages:

  • Fast: O(np)O(np)O(np)
  • Robust to outliers
  • Interpretable: "central tendency"

When to use: Default choice for most applications.

Option 2: Hydrofacies-Conditioned Median

(XT)ij=mediani′:g(i′)=g(i)(Xi′j(std))(X_T)_{ij} = \text{median}_{i': g(i')=g(i)}(X^{(\text{std})}_{i'j})(XT​)ij​=mediani′:g(i′)=g(i)​(Xi′j(std)​)

where g(i)∈{1,…,G}g(i) \in \{1, \ldots, G\}g(i)∈{1,…,G} assigns sample iii to hydrofacies group g(i)g(i)g(i).

Advantages:

  • Accounts for spatial/lithological heterogeneity
  • Different baselines for different aquifer units

When to use: Known hydrofacies/spatial stratification exists.

Option 3: Low-Rank Baseline

XT=arg⁡min⁡L:rank(L)≤r∥X(std)−L∥F2X_T = \arg\min_{L: \text{rank}(L) \leq r} \|X^{(\text{std})} - L\|_F^2XT​=argL:rank(L)≤rmin​∥X(std)−L∥F2​

Solution via truncated SVD:

X(std)=UΣV⊤,XT=UrΣrVr⊤X^{(\text{std})} = U \Sigma V^\top, \quad X_T = U_r \Sigma_r V_r^\topX(std)=UΣV⊤,XT​=Ur​Σr​Vr⊤​

where subscript rrr denotes top-rrr singular values/vectors.

Advantages:

  • Captures geochemical manifold (common patterns)
  • Smooth, low-dimensional baseline

When to use: Strong correlations among ions, clear manifold structure.

Hyperparameter: Rank rrr (typical: 2–5)

Option 4: Robust PCA Baseline

Decomposition:
X(std)=L+SX^{(\text{std})} = L + SX(std)=L+S

where:

  • LLL is low-rank (baseline)
  • SSS is sparse (outliers/anomalies)

Set XT:=LX_T := LXT​:=L.

Iterative algorithm (simplified):

Initialize: L = 0, S = 0
For iteration = 1, ..., max_iter:
    # Update L (low-rank via SVD)
    L ← TruncatedSVD(X - S, rank=r)

    # Update S (sparse via soft thresholding)
    S ← SoftThreshold(X - L, λ)

    # Check convergence
    If ||L - L_old||_F / ||L_old||_F < tol:
        break

Advantages:

  • Robust to sparse outliers
  • Separates systematic (L) from anomalous (S) patterns

When to use: Known sparse contamination events.

Hyperparameters: Rank rrr, sparsity parameter λ\lambdaλ

3. Residuals

R=X(std)−XTR = X^{(\text{std})} - X_TR=X(std)−XT​

Interpretation: Deviations from baseline.

4. Robust Residual Scale

For each ion jjj:

σj=1.4826×MADi(Rij)\sigma_j = 1.4826 \times \text{MAD}_i(R_{ij})σj​=1.4826×MADi​(Rij​)

where:
MADi(Rij)=mediani(∣Rij∣)\text{MAD}_i(R_{ij}) = \text{median}_i(|R_{ij}|)MADi​(Rij​)=mediani​(∣Rij​∣)

Purpose: Normalize residuals to comparable units.

Falsity Channel (F): Perturbation Likelihood

1. Normalized Residuals

uij=∣Rij∣σj+δu_{ij} = \frac{|R_{ij}|}{\sigma_j + \delta}uij​=σj​+δ∣Rij​∣​

where δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 (default: 10−1010^{-10}10−10) prevents division by zero.

Interpretation: uiju_{ij}uij​ measures how many "robust standard deviations" sample iii deviates from baseline for ion jjj.

2. Falsity Map

Fij=gF(uij)F_{ij} = g_F(u_{ij})Fij​=gF​(uij​)

where gF:R≥0→[0,1]g_F: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} \to [0, 1]gF​:R≥0​→[0,1] is a monotone increasing map.

Option 1: Exponential Saturation (Default)

Fij=1−exp⁡(−uij)F_{ij} = 1 - \exp(-u_{ij})Fij​=1−exp(−uij​)

Properties:

  • Fij→0F_{ij} \to 0Fij​→0 as uij→0u_{ij} \to 0uij​→0 (small deviations → low falsity)
  • Fij→1F_{ij} \to 1Fij​→1 as uij→∞u_{ij} \to \inftyuij​→∞ (large deviations → high falsity)
  • Smooth, differentiable
  • No additional hyperparameters

Interpretation: Probability of "falsity" (deviation from baseline) grows exponentially with residual magnitude.

Option 2: Logistic

Fij=11+exp⁡(−a(uij−b))F_{ij} = \frac{1}{1 + \exp(-a(u_{ij} - b))}Fij​=1+exp(−a(uij​−b))1​

Hyperparameters:

  • a>0a > 0a>0: Steepness (default: 2.0)
  • b>0b > 0b>0: Inflection point (default: 1.0)

Properties:

  • Sigmoid shape
  • Fij≈0.5F_{ij} \approx 0.5Fij​≈0.5 when uij≈bu_{ij} \approx buij​≈b
  • Sharper transition than exponential

When to use: Want explicit threshold for "significant" deviations.

3. Bounds

By construction: Fij∈[0,1]F_{ij} \in [0, 1]Fij​∈[0,1].

Indeterminacy Channel (I): Uncertainty

1. Purpose

Capture ambiguity not purely due to residual magnitude:

  • Measurement uncertainty
  • Censoring (below detection limit)
  • Spatial/temporal variability
  • Bootstrap instability

2. Methods

Method 1: Local Heterogeneity (Default)

For spatial/temporal data with neighborhood structure:

Iij=1−exp⁡(−Var(N(i),j)τj+δ)I_{ij} = 1 - \exp\left(-\frac{\text{Var}(\mathcal{N}(i), j)}{\tau_j + \delta}\right)Iij​=1−exp(−τj​+δVar(N(i),j)​)

where:

  • N(i)\mathcal{N}(i)N(i) = neighborhood of sample iii (e.g., kkk nearest spatial/temporal neighbors)
  • Var(N(i),j)\text{Var}(\mathcal{N}(i), j)Var(N(i),j) = variance of ion jjj within neighborhood
  • τj\tau_jτj​ = scale parameter (e.g., median variance)

Interpretation: High local variability → high indeterminacy.

Limitation: Requires spatial/temporal structure.

Method 2: Censoring/Detection Limit

Iij={ιDLif Xij<DLj0otherwiseI_{ij} = \begin{cases} \iota_{\text{DL}} & \text{if } X_{ij} < \text{DL}_j \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}Iij​={ιDL​0​if Xij​<DLj​otherwise​

where ιDL∈(0,1)\iota_{\text{DL}} \in (0, 1)ιDL​∈(0,1) (default: 0.5).

Advantages:

  • Simple, interpretable
  • Directly encodes measurement uncertainty

When to use: Data has known detection limits.

Method 3: Bootstrap Instability

  1. Generate BBB bootstrap samples of the data

  2. Fit encoder on each bootstrap sample

  3. Compute:
    Iij=sdb(X^Tij(b))scaleI_{ij} = \frac{\text{sd}_b(\widehat{X}^{(b)}_{Tij})}{\text{scale}}Iij​=scalesdb​(XTij(b)​)​

    where scale maps to [0,1][0, 1][0,1] (e.g., via percentile).

Advantages:

  • Data-driven uncertainty quantification
  • No domain assumptions

Disadvantages:

  • Computationally expensive (B×B \timesB× encoding cost)

Method 4: Uniform Small Indeterminacy

Iij=ϵI_{ij} = \epsilonIij​=ϵ

for some small ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 (e.g., 0.01).

When to use: No strong uncertainty information; want placeholder.

3. Custom Indeterminacy

User can provide custom function:

def my_indeterminacy(X_std):
    # X_std: (n, p) standardized data
    # Return: (n, p) indeterminacy in [0, 1]
    I = ...
    return I

triplets = encoder.transform(X_std, indeterminacy_func=my_indeterminacy)

Triplet Contract

The encoder must guarantee:

  1. Shape: XT,XI,XFX_T, X_I, X_FXT​,XI​,XF​ have shape (n,p)(n, p)(n,p)
  2. Bounds: Iij,Fij∈[0,1]I_{ij}, F_{ij} \in [0, 1]Iij​,Fij​∈[0,1] for all i,ji, ji,j
  3. Residuals: R=X(std)−XTR = X^{(\text{std})} - X_TR=X(std)−XT​
  4. Reproducibility: Given same X(std)X^{(\text{std})}X(std) and hyperparameters, output is deterministic

Algorithm

Fitting

Input: X(std)∈Rn×pX^{(\text{std})} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}X(std)∈Rn×p, baseline type, hyperparameters

Output: Encoder parameters θ=(σ,metadata)\theta = (\sigma, \text{metadata})θ=(σ,metadata)

1. Compute baseline: X_T ← B(X_std)
2. Compute residuals: R ← X_std - X_T
3. Compute robust scales:
     For j = 1, ..., p:
         σ_j ← 1.4826 × median(|R[:,j]|)
4. Store metadata (baseline type, rank, etc.)
5. Return θ = (σ, metadata)

Transformation

Input: X(std)∈Rn×pX^{(\text{std})} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}X(std)∈Rn×p, parameters θ\thetaθ, optional indeterminacy function

Output: Triplets (XT,XI,XF)(X_T, X_I, X_F)(XT​,XI​,XF​) and residuals RRR

1. Compute baseline: X_T ← B(X_std)
2. Compute residuals: R ← X_std - X_T
3. Compute falsity:
     u ← |R| / (σ + δ)
     F ← g_F(u)  # Apply falsity map
4. Compute indeterminacy:
     If indeterminacy_func provided:
         I ← indeterminacy_func(X_std)
     Else:
         I ← default_indeterminacy(X_std)  # e.g., local variance
5. Clip to bounds: I ← clip(I, 0, 1), F ← clip(F, 0, 1)
6. Return (X_T, X_I, X_F, R)

Properties

1. Baseline Projection

For median baseline:
mediani(XTij)=mediani(Xij(std))\text{median}_i(X_{Tij}) = \text{median}_i(X^{(\text{std})}_{ij})mediani​(XTij​)=mediani​(Xij(std)​)

For low-rank baseline:
rank(XT)≤r\text{rank}(X_T) \leq rrank(XT​)≤r

2. Residual Orthogonality (Low-Rank)

For low-rank baseline via SVD:
⟨XT,R⟩F=0\langle X_T, R \rangle_F = 0⟨XT​,R⟩F​=0

where ⟨A,B⟩F=tr(A⊤B)\langle A, B \rangle_F = \text{tr}(A^\top B)⟨A,B⟩F​=tr(A⊤B) is the Frobenius inner product.

Proof

Theorem: For low-rank baseline via truncated SVD, ⟨XT,R⟩F=0\langle X_T, R \rangle_F = 0⟨XT​,R⟩F​=0.

Proof:

Let X(std)=UΣV⊤X^{(\text{std})} = U\Sigma V^\topX(std)=UΣV⊤ be the full SVD where:

  • U∈Rn×nU \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n}U∈Rn×n (left singular vectors)
  • Σ∈Rn×p\Sigma \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}Σ∈Rn×p (diagonal singular values)
  • V∈Rp×pV \in \mathbb{R}^{p \times p}V∈Rp×p (right singular vectors)

The rank-rrr truncated SVD baseline is:
XT=UrΣrVr⊤X_T = U_r \Sigma_r V_r^\topXT​=Ur​Σr​Vr⊤​

where subscript rrr denotes the top rrr components.

The residual is:
R=X(std)−XT=UΣV⊤−UrΣrVr⊤R = X^{(\text{std})} - X_T = U\Sigma V^\top - U_r \Sigma_r V_r^\topR=X(std)−XT​=UΣV⊤−Ur​Σr​Vr⊤​

Partition the SVD:
U=[Ur∣Ur+1:n],Σ=[Σr00Σr+1:n],V=[Vr∣Vr+1:p]U = [U_r \mid U_{r+1:n}], \quad \Sigma = \begin{bmatrix} \Sigma_r & 0 \\ 0 & \Sigma_{r+1:n} \end{bmatrix}, \quad V = [V_r \mid V_{r+1:p}]U=[Ur​∣Ur+1:n​],Σ=[Σr​0​0Σr+1:n​​],V=[Vr​∣Vr+1:p​]

Then:
X(std)=UrΣrVr⊤+Ur+1:nΣr+1:nVr+1:p⊤X^{(\text{std})} = U_r \Sigma_r V_r^\top + U_{r+1:n} \Sigma_{r+1:n} V_{r+1:p}^\topX(std)=Ur​Σr​Vr⊤​+Ur+1:n​Σr+1:n​Vr+1:p⊤​

So:
R=Ur+1:nΣr+1:nVr+1:p⊤R = U_{r+1:n} \Sigma_{r+1:n} V_{r+1:p}^\topR=Ur+1:n​Σr+1:n​Vr+1:p⊤​

The Frobenius inner product is:
⟨XT,R⟩F=tr(XT⊤R)\langle X_T, R \rangle_F = \text{tr}(X_T^\top R)⟨XT​,R⟩F​=tr(XT⊤​R)

=tr[(VrΣrUr⊤)⊤(Ur+1:nΣr+1:nVr+1:p⊤)]= \text{tr}\left[(V_r \Sigma_r U_r^\top)^\top (U_{r+1:n} \Sigma_{r+1:n} V_{r+1:p}^\top)\right]=tr[(Vr​Σr​Ur⊤​)⊤(Ur+1:n​Σr+1:n​Vr+1:p⊤​)]

=tr[VrΣrUr⊤Ur+1:nΣr+1:nVr+1:p⊤]= \text{tr}\left[V_r \Sigma_r U_r^\top U_{r+1:n} \Sigma_{r+1:n} V_{r+1:p}^\top\right]=tr[Vr​Σr​Ur⊤​Ur+1:n​Σr+1:n​Vr+1:p⊤​]

Since UUU is orthogonal: Ur⊤Ur+1:n=0U_r^\top U_{r+1:n} = 0Ur⊤​Ur+1:n​=0

Therefore:
⟨XT,R⟩F=0\langle X_T, R \rangle_F = 0⟨XT​,R⟩F​=0

□\square□

Interpretation: The low-rank baseline and residual are orthogonal in Frobenius space, implying no correlation between baseline patterns and deviations.

3. Falsity Monotonicity

∣Rij∣<∣Rkj∣  ⟹  Fij<Fkj|R_{ij}| < |R_{kj}| \implies F_{ij} < F_{kj}∣Rij​∣<∣Rkj​∣⟹Fij​<Fkj​

Larger deviations always have higher falsity.

Proof

Theorem: For exponential falsity map Fij=1−exp⁡(−uij)F_{ij} = 1 - \exp(-u_{ij})Fij​=1−exp(−uij​) where uij=∣Rij∣/(σj+δ)u_{ij} = |R_{ij}|/(\sigma_j + \delta)uij​=∣Rij​∣/(σj​+δ), falsity is strictly monotone increasing in ∣Rij∣|R_{ij}|∣Rij​∣.

Proof:

Consider the falsity map:
Fij=gF(uij)=1−exp⁡(−uij)F_{ij} = g_F(u_{ij}) = 1 - \exp(-u_{ij})Fij​=gF​(uij​)=1−exp(−uij​)

where:
uij=∣Rij∣σj+δu_{ij} = \frac{|R_{ij}|}{\sigma_j + \delta}uij​=σj​+δ∣Rij​∣​

For fixed ion jjj, we have:
∂Fij∂uij=∂∂u[1−exp⁡(−u)]=exp⁡(−u)>0∀u≥0\frac{\partial F_{ij}}{\partial u_{ij}} = \frac{\partial}{\partial u}[1 - \exp(-u)] = \exp(-u) > 0 \quad \forall u \geq 0∂uij​∂Fij​​=∂u∂​[1−exp(−u)]=exp(−u)>0∀u≥0

Since ∂F/∂u>0\partial F/\partial u > 0∂F/∂u>0, the map is strictly increasing.

Furthermore:
∂uij∂∣Rij∣=1σj+δ>0\frac{\partial u_{ij}}{\partial |R_{ij}|} = \frac{1}{\sigma_j + \delta} > 0∂∣Rij​∣∂uij​​=σj​+δ1​>0

By chain rule:
∂Fij∂∣Rij∣=∂Fij∂uij⋅∂uij∂∣Rij∣>0\frac{\partial F_{ij}}{\partial |R_{ij}|} = \frac{\partial F_{ij}}{\partial u_{ij}} \cdot \frac{\partial u_{ij}}{\partial |R_{ij}|} > 0∂∣Rij​∣∂Fij​​=∂uij​∂Fij​​⋅∂∣Rij​∣∂uij​​>0

Therefore:
∣Rij∣<∣Rkj∣  ⟹  uij<ukj  ⟹  Fij<Fkj|R_{ij}| < |R_{kj}| \implies u_{ij} < u_{kj} \implies F_{ij} < F_{kj}∣Rij​∣<∣Rkj​∣⟹uij​<ukj​⟹Fij​<Fkj​

□\square□

Note: For logistic falsity map Fij=1/(1+exp⁡(−a(uij−b)))F_{ij} = 1/(1 + \exp(-a(u_{ij} - b)))Fij​=1/(1+exp(−a(uij​−b))), the same result holds since:
∂F∂u=aexp⁡(−a(u−b))[1+exp⁡(−a(u−b))]2>0∀u\frac{\partial F}{\partial u} = \frac{a \exp(-a(u-b))}{[1 + \exp(-a(u-b))]^2} > 0 \quad \forall u∂u∂F​=[1+exp(−a(u−b))]2aexp(−a(u−b))​>0∀u

4. Independence of Channels

(T,I,F)(T, I, F)(T,I,F) are conceptually independent:

  • TTT captures baseline
  • III captures uncertainty (may be independent of baseline)
  • FFF captures perturbations (derived from R=X(std)−TR = X^{(\text{std})} - TR=X(std)−T)

Hyperparameter Selection

Parameter Values Selection Criterion
baseline_type median, low_rank, robust_pca Domain knowledge, exploratory analysis
baseline_rank 2–10 Scree plot, explained variance
falsity_map exponential, logistic Default: exponential (no tuning)
falsity_params (logistic) a∈[1,5]a \in [1, 5]a∈[1,5], b∈[0.5,2]b \in [0.5, 2]b∈[0.5,2] Cross-validation on downstream task

Usage Example 

from neutrohydro.encoder import NDGEncoder, BaselineType, FalsityMap

# Option 1: Simple median baseline
encoder = NDGEncoder(baseline_type="median")
encoder.fit(X_std)
triplets = encoder.transform(X_std)

# Option 2: Low-rank baseline
encoder = NDGEncoder(
    baseline_type=BaselineType.LOW_RANK,
    baseline_rank=3
)
triplets = encoder.fit_transform(X_std)

# Option 3: Custom indeterminacy
def detection_limit_I(X_std):
    # Assume we have original X and DL
    I = np.zeros_like(X_std)
    I[X < DL] = 0.5
    return I

triplets = encoder.transform(X_std, indeterminacy_func=detection_limit_I)

# Access components
print(f"Truth shape: {triplets.T.shape}")
print(f"Indeterminacy range: [{triplets.I.min():.3f}, {triplets.I.max():.3f}]")
print(f"Falsity range: [{triplets.F.min():.3f}, {triplets.F.max():.3f}]")

Diagnostics

1. Baseline Quality

For low-rank baseline, check explained variance:

EV(r)=∑i=1rσi2∑i=1min⁡(n,p)σi2\text{EV}(r) = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^r \sigma_i^2}{\sum_{i=1}^{\min(n,p)} \sigma_i^2}EV(r)=∑i=1min(n,p)​σi2​∑i=1r​σi2​​

where σi\sigma_iσi​ are singular values.

Rule of thumb: EV(r)>0.7\text{EV}(r) > 0.7EV(r)>0.7 for good baseline.

2. Residual Distribution

Plot histogram of normalized residuals uiju_{ij}uij​:

  • Unimodal near 0: Baseline captures central tendency well
  • Bimodal: May have distinct populations (consider hydrofacies)
  • Heavy tails: Many outliers (robust PCA may help)

3. Falsity Patterns

Plot FijF_{ij}Fij​ vs. iii (sample index):

  • Random scatter: No systematic pattern (good)
  • Clusters: May indicate contamination events or spatial patterns
  • All high/low: Baseline may be poor fit

4. Channel Correlations

Compute:
corr(Fj,Ij)=corr(F:,j,I:,j)\text{corr}(F_j, I_j) = \text{corr}(F_{:,j}, I_{:,j})corr(Fj​,Ij​)=corr(F:,j​,I:,j​)

Expected: Low correlation (channels capture different aspects)

High correlation: May indicate redundancy or poor indeterminacy definition

Interpretation

Truth Channel TTT

  • Physical meaning: "Expected" or "reference" concentration
  • Baseline = median: Central tendency across all samples
  • Baseline = low-rank: Typical geochemical pattern
  • Values: Typically close to 0 (since data is standardized)

Indeterminacy Channel III

  • Physical meaning: Degree of uncertainty/ambiguity
  • High III: Measurement uncertain, censored, or highly variable
  • Low III: Well-measured, confident value
  • Range: [0,1][0, 1][0,1] by construction

Falsity Channel FFF

  • Physical meaning: Likelihood of deviation from baseline
  • High FFF: Anomalous, contaminated, or perturbed
  • Low FFF: Consistent with baseline
  • Range: [0,1][0, 1][0,1] by construction

References

  1. Smarandache, F. (1998). Neutrosophy: Neutrosophic probability, set, and logic. American Research Press.

  2. Candès, E. J., Li, X., Ma, Y., & Wright, J. (2011). Robust principal component analysis? Journal of the ACM, 58(3), 1-37.

  3. Reimann, C., Filzmoser, P., Garrett, R. G., & Dutter, R. (2008). Statistical data analysis explained: Applied environmental statistics with R. John Wiley & Sons.

Next: PNPLS Model - Regression in augmented neutrosophic space.

\newpage

PNPLS: Probabilistic Neutrosophic PLS

Module: neutrohydro.model

Overview

PNPLS extends Partial Least Squares (PLS) regression to neutrosophic triplet data (T,I,F)(T, I, F)(T,I,F) by:

  1. Constructing an augmented predictor space combining the three channels
  2. Applying elementwise precision weights based on falsity
  3. Fitting PLS via the NIPALS algorithm in this augmented Hilbert space

Mathematical Foundation

1. Input

From NDG encoder:

  • Triplet channels: XT,XI,XF∈Rn×pX_T, X_I, X_F \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times p}XT​,XI​,XF​∈Rn×p
  • Standardized target: y(std)∈Rny^{(\text{std})} \in \mathbb{R}^ny(std)∈Rn

2. Augmented Predictor Space

2.1 Channel Concatenation

X(aug)=[ XTρIXIρFXF ]∈Rn×3pX^{(\text{aug})} = \left[\, X_T \quad \sqrt{\rho_I} X_I \quad \sqrt{\rho_F} X_F \,\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times 3p}X(aug)=[XT​ρI​​XI​ρF​​XF​]∈Rn×3p

Channel weights:

  • ρT=1\rho_T = 1ρT​=1 (Truth channel, always included)
  • ρI≥0\rho_I \geq 0ρI​≥0 (Indeterminacy weight, default: 1)
  • ρF≥0\rho_F \geq 0ρF​≥0 (Falsity weight, default: 1)

2.2 Induced Inner Product

The augmented space R3p\mathbb{R}^{3p}R3p has inner product:

⟨u,v⟩N=uT⊤vT+ρIuI⊤vI+ρFuF⊤vF\langle u, v \rangle_{\mathcal{N}} = u_T^\top v_T + \rho_I u_I^\top v_I + \rho_F u_F^\top v_F⟨u,v⟩N​=uT⊤​vT​+ρI​uI⊤​vI​+ρF​uF⊤​vF​

where u=[uT⊤,uI⊤,uF⊤]⊤u = [u_T^\top, u_I^\top, u_F^\top]^\topu=[uT⊤​,uI⊤​,uF⊤​]⊤ and similarly for vvv.

Properties:

  • Positive definite (since ρI,ρF≥0\rho_I, \rho_F \geq 0ρI​,ρF​≥0)
  • Euclidean structure preserved
  • Well-defined projections and orthogonality

3. Precision Weighting

3.1 Elementwise Weights from Falsity

Wij=exp⁡(−λF⋅Fij)W_{ij} = \exp(-\lambda_F \cdot F_{ij})Wij​=exp(−λF​⋅Fij​)

where λF>0\lambda_F > 0λF​>0 controls downweighting strength.

Interpretation:

  • High falsity Fij≈1F_{ij} \approx 1Fij​≈1 → low weight Wij≈exp⁡(−λF)W_{ij} \approx \exp(-\lambda_F)Wij​≈exp(−λF​)
  • Low falsity Fij≈0F_{ij} \approx 0Fij​≈0 → high weight Wij≈1W_{ij} \approx 1Wij​≈1

Effect: Observations with large deviations from baseline contribute less to covariance estimation.

3.2 Extension to Augmented Space

Repeat weights for all three channels:

W(aug)=[ WWW ]∈Rn×3pW^{(\text{aug})} = \left[\, W \quad W \quad W \,\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times 3p}W(aug)=[WWW]∈Rn×3p

3.3 Weighted Predictors

X~(aug)=W(aug)⊙X(aug)\widetilde{X}^{(\text{aug})} = W^{(\text{aug})} \odot X^{(\text{aug})}X(aug)=W(aug)⊙X(aug)

where ⊙\odot⊙ is elementwise (Hadamard) product.

Result: X~ij(aug)\widetilde{X}^{(\text{aug})}_{ij}Xij(aug)​ is downweighted if sample iii has high falsity for ion jjj.

PLS1 via NIPALS

4. NIPALS Algorithm

Input: X~(aug)∈Rn×3p\widetilde{X}^{(\text{aug})} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times 3p}X(aug)∈Rn×3p, y(std)∈Rny^{(\text{std})} \in \mathbb{R}^ny(std)∈Rn, kkk components

Output: Latent components (T,W,P,q,β)(T, W, P, q, \beta)(T,W,P,q,β)

Initialization 

X_deflated ← X̃^(aug)
y_deflated ← y^(std)
T ← zeros(n, k)  # Scores
W ← zeros(3p, k)  # Weights
P ← zeros(3p, k)  # Loadings
q ← zeros(k)      # Response loadings

Component Extraction (for h = 1, ..., k)

Step 1: Initialize weight vector

wh=Xdeflated⊤ydeflated∥Xdeflated⊤ydeflated∥w_h = \frac{X_{\text{deflated}}^\top y_{\text{deflated}}}{\|X_{\text{deflated}}^\top y_{\text{deflated}}\|}wh​=∥Xdeflated⊤​ydeflated​∥Xdeflated⊤​ydeflated​​

Step 2: Iterative refinement (until convergence)

Repeat:
wold←whw_{\text{old}} \leftarrow w_hwold​←wh​
# Score
th←Xdeflated⋅wht_h \leftarrow X_{\text{deflated}} \cdot w_hth​←Xdeflated​⋅wh​
th←th∥th∥t_h \leftarrow \frac{t_h}{\|t_h\|}th​←∥th​∥th​​
# Weight update
wh←Xdeflated⊤⋅thw_h \leftarrow X_{\text{deflated}}^\top \cdot t_hwh​←Xdeflated⊤​⋅th​
wh←wh∥wh∥w_h \leftarrow \frac{w_h}{\|w_h\|}wh​←∥wh​∥wh​​
Until ∥wh−wold∥<tol\|w_h - w_{\text{old}}\| < \text{tol}∥wh​−wold​∥<tol

Step 3: Final score and loadings

th=Xdeflatedwht_h = X_{\text{deflated}} w_hth​=Xdeflated​wh​

ph=Xdeflated⊤thth⊤thp_h = \frac{X_{\text{deflated}}^\top t_h}{t_h^\top t_h}ph​=th⊤​th​Xdeflated⊤​th​​

qh=ydeflated⊤thth⊤thq_h = \frac{y_{\text{deflated}}^\top t_h}{t_h^\top t_h}qh​=th⊤​th​ydeflated⊤​th​​

Step 4: Deflation

Xdeflated←Xdeflated−thph⊤X_{\text{deflated}} \leftarrow X_{\text{deflated}} - t_h p_h^\topXdeflated​←Xdeflated​−th​ph⊤​

ydeflated←ydeflated−thqhy_{\text{deflated}} \leftarrow y_{\text{deflated}} - t_h q_hydeflated​←ydeflated​−th​qh​

Step 5: Store

T[:,h]←thT[:,h] \leftarrow t_hT[:,h]←th​
W[:,h]←whW[:,h] \leftarrow w_hW[:,h]←wh​
P[:,h]←phP[:,h] \leftarrow p_hP[:,h]←ph​
q[h]←qhq[h] \leftarrow q_hq[h]←qh​

Regression Coefficients

After extracting kkk components:

β=W(P⊤W)−1q\beta = W (P^\top W)^{-1} qβ=W(P⊤W)−1q

If P⊤WP^\top WP⊤W is singular, use pseudo-inverse:

β=W(P⊤W)+q\beta = W (P^\top W)^+ qβ=W(P⊤W)+q

5. Prediction

For new triplet data (X~new(aug))(\widetilde{X}_{\text{new}}^{(\text{aug})})(Xnew(aug)​):

y^new=X~new(aug)β\hat{y}_{\text{new}} = \widetilde{X}_{\text{new}}^{(\text{aug})} \betay^​new​=Xnew(aug)​β

Transform back to original scale using preprocessing parameters.

Handling Missing Data

6. EM-Like Imputation

For missing values in original XXX, extended to augmented space:

E-Step: Imputation

Current reconstruction from kkk components:

X^(aug)=TP⊤\widehat{X}^{(\text{aug})} = T P^\topX(aug)=TP⊤

Impute missing entries:

Xcomplete(aug)=M(aug)⊙X(aug)+(1−M(aug))⊙X^(aug)X^{(\text{aug})}_{\text{complete}} = M^{(\text{aug})} \odot X^{(\text{aug})} + (1 - M^{(\text{aug})}) \odot \widehat{X}^{(\text{aug})}Xcomplete(aug)​=M(aug)⊙X(aug)+(1−M(aug))⊙X(aug)

where M(aug)∈{0,1}n×3pM^{(\text{aug})} \in \{0, 1\}^{n \times 3p}M(aug)∈{0,1}n×3p is the missingness mask.

M-Step: Refit PLS

Run NIPALS on Xcomplete(aug)X^{(\text{aug})}_{\text{complete}}Xcomplete(aug)​ to update (T,W,P,q,β)(T, W, P, q, \beta)(T,W,P,q,β).

Convergence

Iterate E-step and M-step until:

∥β(t+1)−β(t)∥∥β(t)∥<tolEM\frac{\|\beta^{(t+1)} - \beta^{(t)}\|}{\|\beta^{(t)}\|} < \text{tol}_{\text{EM}}∥β(t)∥∥β(t+1)−β(t)∥​<tolEM​

Typically: 10–20 iterations suffice.

Model Diagnostics

7. Explained Variance

For component hhh:

SSYh=qh2⋅(th⊤th)\text{SSY}_h = q_h^2 \cdot (t_h^\top t_h)SSYh​=qh2​⋅(th⊤​th​)

Cumulative explained variance:

Rcumul2(k)=∑h=1kSSYh∥y(std)∥2R^2_{\text{cumul}}(k) = \frac{\sum_{h=1}^k \text{SSY}_h}{\|y^{(\text{std})}\|^2}Rcumul2​(k)=∥y(std)∥2∑h=1k​SSYh​​

Typical behavior: First few components explain most variance; diminishing returns after.

8. Q² (Predictive Quality)

Use cross-validation:

Q2=1−∑i(yi−y^i(CV))2∑i(yi−yˉ)2Q^2 = 1 - \frac{\sum_i (y_i - \hat{y}_i^{(\text{CV})})^2}{\sum_i (y_i - \bar{y})^2}Q2=1−∑i​(yi​−yˉ​)2∑i​(yi​−y^​i(CV)​)2​

where y^i(CV)\hat{y}_i^{(\text{CV})}y^​i(CV)​ is prediction with sample iii excluded.

9. Coefficient Partitioning

Partition β∈R3p\beta \in \mathbb{R}^{3p}β∈R3p into channels:

β=[βTβIβF],βT,βI,βF∈Rp\beta = \begin{bmatrix} \beta_T \\ \beta_I \\ \beta_F \end{bmatrix}, \quad \beta_T, \beta_I, \beta_F \in \mathbb{R}^pβ=​βT​βI​βF​​​,βT​,βI​,βF​∈Rp

Interpretation:

  • βT(j)\beta_T(j)βT​(j): Contribution of baseline ion jjj
  • βI(j)\beta_I(j)βI​(j): Contribution of indeterminacy for ion jjj
  • βF(j)\beta_F(j)βF​(j): Contribution of falsity for ion jjj

Net contribution for sample iii, ion jjj:

cij=(X~T)ijβT(j)+(X~I)ijβI(j)+(X~F)ijβF(j)c_{ij} = (\widetilde{X}_T)_{ij} \beta_T(j) + (\widetilde{X}_I)_{ij} \beta_I(j) + (\widetilde{X}_F)_{ij} \beta_F(j)cij​=(XT​)ij​βT​(j)+(XI​)ij​βI​(j)+(XF​)ij​βF​(j)

Properties

10. Optimality (Standard PLS)

Standard PLS maximizes covariance between scores and response:

max⁡wCov(Xw,y)s.t.∥w∥=1\max_{w} \text{Cov}(Xw, y) \quad \text{s.t.} \quad \|w\| = 1wmax​Cov(Xw,y)s.t.∥w∥=1

PNPLS extension: Operates in augmented space X~(aug)\widetilde{X}^{(\text{aug})}X(aug), inheriting PLS optimality.

11. Multicollinearity Handling

PLS naturally handles multicollinearity (unlike ordinary least squares):

  • Extracts latent components capturing correlated structure
  • Stable even when p≫np \gg np≫n

12. Relationship to PCR

PCR (Principal Component Regression):

  1. Compute PCA of XXX
  2. Regress yyy on principal components

PLS (includes PNPLS):

  1. Extract components maximizing covariance with yyy
  2. Directly optimizes prediction

Result: PLS typically outperforms PCR for prediction.

13. NIPALS Convergence

The NIPALS algorithm (Section 4) iteratively refines weight vectors. We prove convergence.

Theorem: NIPALS Convergence

Theorem: For non-zero data matrix XXX and target yyy, the NIPALS iterative update:

w(t+1)=XTt(t)/∣∣XTt(t)∣∣w^{(t+1)} = X^T t^{(t)} / ||X^T t^{(t)}||w(t+1)=XTt(t)/∣∣XTt(t)∣∣
t(t+1)=Xw(t+1)/∣∣Xw(t+1)∣∣t^{(t+1)} = X w^{(t+1)} / ||X w^{(t+1)}||t(t+1)=Xw(t+1)/∣∣Xw(t+1)∣∣

converges to the leading left and right singular vectors of the matrix XTyyTXX^T y y^T XXTyyTX (scaled by norms).

Proof:

Consider the NIPALS iteration for component hhh:

Initialization: wh(0)=XTy/∥XTy∥w_h^{(0)} = X^T y / \|X^T y\|wh(0)​=XTy/∥XTy∥

Iteration t=0,1,2,…t = 0, 1, 2, \ldotst=0,1,2,…:

  1. th(t)=Xwh(t)/∥Xwh(t)∥t_h^{(t)} = X w_h^{(t)} / \|X w_h^{(t)}\|th(t)​=Xwh(t)​/∥Xwh(t)​∥
  2. wh(t+1)=XTth(t)/∥XTth(t)∥w_h^{(t+1)} = X^T t_h^{(t)} / \|X^T t_h^{(t)}\|wh(t+1)​=XTth(t)​/∥XTth(t)​∥

Combine steps:
wh(t+1)=XT(Xwh(t)/∥Xwh(t)∥)∥XT(Xwh(t)/∥Xwh(t)∥)∥w_h^{(t+1)} = \frac{X^T (X w_h^{(t)} / \|X w_h^{(t)}\|)}{\|X^T (X w_h^{(t)} / \|X w_h^{(t)}\|)\|}wh(t+1)​=∥XT(Xwh(t)​/∥Xwh(t)​∥)∥XT(Xwh(t)​/∥Xwh(t)​∥)​

Let M=XTXM = X^T XM=XTX. Then (ignoring normalization momentarily):
wh(t+1)∝XTXwh(t)=Mwh(t)w_h^{(t+1)} \propto X^T X w_h^{(t)} = M w_h^{(t)}wh(t+1)​∝XTXwh(t)​=Mwh(t)​

wh(t)∝Mtwh(0)w_h^{(t)} \propto M^t w_h^{(0)}wh(t)​∝Mtwh(0)​

This is the power method applied to matrix M=XTXM = X^T XM=XTX.

Convergence of Power Method:

Let M=XTXM = X^T XM=XTX have eigendecomposition:
M=VΛVTM = V \Lambda V^TM=VΛVT

where λ1≥λ2≥…≥λp≥0\lambda_1 \geq \lambda_2 \geq \ldots \geq \lambda_p \geq 0λ1​≥λ2​≥…≥λp​≥0 and V=[v1∣v2∣…∣vp]V = [v_1 \mid v_2 \mid \ldots \mid v_p]V=[v1​∣v2​∣…∣vp​] are orthonormal eigenvectors.

Expand initial vector:
wh(0)=∑i=1pαiviw_h^{(0)} = \sum_{i=1}^p \alpha_i v_iwh(0)​=i=1∑p​αi​vi​

After ttt iterations:
Mtwh(0)=∑i=1pαiλitvi=λ1t(α1v1+∑i=2pαi(λiλ1)tvi)M^t w_h^{(0)} = \sum_{i=1}^p \alpha_i \lambda_i^t v_i = \lambda_1^t \left(\alpha_1 v_1 + \sum_{i=2}^p \alpha_i \left(\frac{\lambda_i}{\lambda_1}\right)^t v_i\right)Mtwh(0)​=i=1∑p​αi​λit​vi​=λ1t​(α1​v1​+i=2∑p​αi​(λ1​λi​​)tvi​)

Since ∣λi/λ1∣<1|\lambda_i/\lambda_1| < 1∣λi​/λ1​∣<1 for i>1i > 1i>1:
lim⁡t→∞Mtwh(0)∥Mtwh(0)∥=±v1\lim_{t \to \infty} \frac{M^t w_h^{(0)}}{\|M^t w_h^{(0)}\|} = \pm v_1t→∞lim​∥Mtwh(0)​∥Mtwh(0)​​=±v1​

(assuming α1≠0\alpha_1 \neq 0α1​=0, which holds generically).

Convergence Rate:
∥wh(t)−v1∥=O(∣λ2λ1∣t)\|w_h^{(t)} - v_1\| = O\left(\left|\frac{\lambda_2}{\lambda_1}\right|^t\right)∥wh(t)​−v1​∥=O(​λ1​λ2​​​t)

Practical implication: NIPALS converges exponentially fast when the leading eigenvalue is well-separated from the second eigenvalue.

□\square□

Corollary: Convergence Tolerance

Typical tolerance: ∥wh(t+1)−wh(t)∥<ϵ\|w_h^{(t+1)} - w_h^{(t)}\| < \epsilon∥wh(t+1)​−wh(t)​∥<ϵ with ϵ=10−6\epsilon = 10^{-6}ϵ=10−6.

Expected iterations: t≈log⁡(ϵ)/log⁡(∣λ2/λ1∣)t \approx \log(\epsilon) / \log(|\lambda_2/\lambda_1|)t≈log(ϵ)/log(∣λ2​/λ1​∣).

For typical data with λ1/λ2≈2\lambda_1/\lambda_2 \approx 2λ1​/λ2​≈2–5, convergence in 5–15 iterations.

Hyperparameters

Parameter Range Default Selection Method
kkk (components) 1–20 5 Cross-validation (minimize RMSE)
ρI\rho_IρI​ [0.1, 5] 1.0 Grid search or domain knowledge
ρF\rho_FρF​ [0.1, 5] 1.0 Grid search or domain knowledge
λF\lambda_FλF​ [0.1, 10] 1.0 Cross-validation

Component Selection

Elbow method: Plot explained variance vs. kkk; choose kkk at "elbow".

Cross-validation:

  • For k=1,…,kmax⁡k = 1, \ldots, k_{\max}k=1,…,kmax​:
    • Compute Q2(k)Q^2(k)Q2(k) via cross-validation
  • Select kkk maximizing Q2Q^2Q2

Heuristic: Start with k=5k = 5k=5; increase if underfitting, decrease if overfitting.

Channel Weights

Equal weights (ρI=ρF=1\rho_I = \rho_F = 1ρI​=ρF​=1): Default, balanced approach.

Emphasize uncertainty (ρI>1\rho_I > 1ρI​>1): If uncertainty is critical (e.g., censored data).

Emphasize perturbations (ρF>1\rho_F > 1ρF​>1): If anomalies are primary interest.

Falsity Weighting Strength

Low λF\lambda_FλF​ (≈ 0.5): Mild downweighting, inclusive of outliers.

High λF\lambda_FλF​ (≈ 5): Strong downweighting, robust to anomalies.

Optimal: Often around λF∈[1,2]\lambda_F \in [1, 2]λF​∈[1,2].

Algorithm Complexity

Operation Complexity
Single NIPALS iteration O(np)O(np)O(np)
Single component (converged) O(Iconv⋅np)O(I_{conv} \cdot np)O(Iconv​⋅np) where Iconv≈5I_{conv} \approx 5Iconv​≈5–10
Full PLS (kkk components) O(knp)O(knp)O(knp)
EM imputation (IEMI_{EM}IEM​ iterations) O(IEM⋅knp)O(I_{EM} \cdot knp)O(IEM​⋅knp) where IEM≈10I_{EM} \approx 10IEM​≈10–20

Total: O(knp)O(knp)O(knp) for complete data, O(IEM⋅knp)O(I_{EM} \cdot knp)O(IEM​⋅knp) with missing data.

Usage Example 

from neutrohydro.model import PNPLS

# Initialize
model = PNPLS(
    n_components=5,
    rho_I=1.0,
    rho_F=1.0,
    lambda_F=1.0,
    tol=1e-6,
    max_iter=500
)

# Fit on triplets and target
model.fit(triplets, y_std)

# Predictions
y_pred_std = model.predict(triplets)

# Score (R²)
r2 = model.score(triplets, y_std)
print(f"R² = {r2:.4f}")

# Get coefficients by channel
coeffs = model.get_coefficients()
print(f"Truth coefficients: {coeffs['beta_T']}")

# Get weights by channel (for NVIP)
weights = model.get_weights_by_channel()
W_T = weights['W_T']  # Shape: (p, k)

Robustness Optional Built-in (falsity weighting)
Uncertainty Not explicit Explicit (I channel)
Baseline Not explicit Explicit (T channel)
Missing data Various methods EM imputation
Complexity O(knp)O(knp)O(knp) O(3knp)=O(knp)O(3knp) = O(knp)O(3knp)=O(knp) (same order)

Next: NVIP - Decomposing variable importance across neutrosophic channels.

\newpage

NVIP: Neutrosophic Variable Importance in Projection

Module: neutrohydro.nvip

Overview

NVIP extends the classical VIP (Variable Importance in Projection) metric to neutrosophic triplet data, enabling L2-additive decomposition of variable importance across Truth, Indeterminacy, and Falsity channels.

Core Innovation: Variable importance can be unambiguously partitioned into baseline and perturbation components.

Mathematical Foundation

1. Classical VIP (Standard PLS)

For standard PLS with kkk components, the VIP for variable jjj is:

VIP(j)=p⋅∑h=1kSSYh⋅wh2(j)∥wh∥2∑h=1kSSYh\text{VIP}(j) = \sqrt{p \cdot \frac{\sum_{h=1}^k \text{SSY}_h \cdot \frac{w_h^2(j)}{\|w_h\|^2}}{\sum_{h=1}^k \text{SSY}_h}}VIP(j)=p⋅∑h=1k​SSYh​∑h=1k​SSYh​⋅∥wh​∥2wh2​(j)​​​

where:

  • ppp = number of variables
  • SSYh=qh2⋅(th⊤th)\text{SSY}_h = q_h^2 \cdot (t_h^\top t_h)SSYh​=qh2​⋅(th⊤​th​) = response variance explained by component hhh
  • wh(j)w_h(j)wh​(j) = weight for variable jjj in component hhh

Interpretation: VIP(j)≥1(j) \geq 1(j)≥1 indicates variable jjj is important for prediction.

Property: ∑j=1pVIP2(j)=p\sum_{j=1}^p \text{VIP}^2(j) = p∑j=1p​VIP2(j)=p

2. NVIP Extension

For PNPLS with augmented space R3p\mathbb{R}^{3p}R3p:

Weight Partitioning

wh=[wT,hwI,hwF,h]∈R3pw_h = \begin{bmatrix} w_{T,h} \\ w_{I,h} \\ w_{F,h} \end{bmatrix} \in \mathbb{R}^{3p}wh​=​wT,h​wI,h​wF,h​​​∈R3p

where wT,h,wI,h,wF,h∈Rpw_{T,h}, w_{I,h}, w_{F,h} \in \mathbb{R}^pwT,h​,wI,h​,wF,h​∈Rp are weights for each channel.

Per-Variable, Per-Channel Squared Weights

ωT,h(j)=wT,h2(j)\omega_{T,h}(j) = w_{T,h}^2(j)ωT,h​(j)=wT,h2​(j)
ωI,h(j)=wI,h2(j)\omega_{I,h}(j) = w_{I,h}^2(j)ωI,h​(j)=wI,h2​(j)
ωF,h(j)=wF,h2(j)\omega_{F,h}(j) = w_{F,h}^2(j)ωF,h​(j)=wF,h2​(j)

Total Squared Weight (Normalization)

Ωh=∑m=1p[ωT,h(m)+ωI,h(m)+ωF,h(m)]=∥wh∥2\Omega_h = \sum_{m=1}^p \left[\omega_{T,h}(m) + \omega_{I,h}(m) + \omega_{F,h}(m)\right] = \|w_h\|^2Ωh​=m=1∑p​[ωT,h​(m)+ωI,h​(m)+ωF,h​(m)]=∥wh​∥2

Channel-Wise VIP Definitions

Truth VIP:

VIPT(j)=p⋅∑h=1kSSYh⋅ωT,h(j)Ωh∑h=1kSSYh\text{VIP}_T(j) = \sqrt{p \cdot \frac{\sum_{h=1}^k \text{SSY}_h \cdot \frac{\omega_{T,h}(j)}{\Omega_h}}{\sum_{h=1}^k \text{SSY}_h}}VIPT​(j)=p⋅∑h=1k​SSYh​∑h=1k​SSYh​⋅Ωh​ωT,h​(j)​​​

Indeterminacy VIP:

VIPI(j)=p⋅∑h=1kSSYh⋅ωI,h(j)Ωh∑h=1kSSYh\text{VIP}_I(j) = \sqrt{p \cdot \frac{\sum_{h=1}^k \text{SSY}_h \cdot \frac{\omega_{I,h}(j)}{\Omega_h}}{\sum_{h=1}^k \text{SSY}_h}}VIPI​(j)=p⋅∑h=1k​SSYh​∑h=1k​SSYh​⋅Ωh​ωI,h​(j)​​​

Falsity VIP:

VIPF(j)=p⋅∑h=1kSSYh⋅ωF,h(j)Ωh∑h=1kSSYh\text{VIP}_F(j) = \sqrt{p \cdot \frac{\sum_{h=1}^k \text{SSY}_h \cdot \frac{\omega_{F,h}(j)}{\Omega_h}}{\sum_{h=1}^k \text{SSY}_h}}VIPF​(j)=p⋅∑h=1k​SSYh​∑h=1k​SSYh​⋅Ωh​ωF,h​(j)​​​

Aggregated VIP:

VIPagg(j)=p⋅∑h=1kSSYh⋅ωT,h(j)+ωI,h(j)+ωF,h(j)Ωh∑h=1kSSYh\text{VIP}_{\text{agg}}(j) = \sqrt{p \cdot \frac{\sum_{h=1}^k \text{SSY}_h \cdot \frac{\omega_{T,h}(j) + \omega_{I,h}(j) + \omega_{F,h}(j)}{\Omega_h}}{\sum_{h=1}^k \text{SSY}_h}}VIPagg​(j)=p⋅∑h=1k​SSYh​∑h=1k​SSYh​⋅Ωh​ωT,h​(j)+ωI,h​(j)+ωF,h​(j)​​​

L2 Decomposition Theorem

3. Main Result

Theorem (NVIP L2 Additivity):

For each variable j=1,…,pj = 1, \ldots, pj=1,…,p:

VIPagg2(j)=VIPT2(j)+VIPI2(j)+VIPF2(j)\boxed{\text{VIP}_{\text{agg}}^2(j) = \text{VIP}_T^2(j) + \text{VIP}_I^2(j) + \text{VIP}_F^2(j)}VIPagg2​(j)=VIPT2​(j)+VIPI2​(j)+VIPF2​(j)​

4. Proof

Define energies:

ET(j)=VIPT2(j),EI(j)=VIPI2(j),EF(j)=VIPF2(j)E_T(j) = \text{VIP}_T^2(j), \quad E_I(j) = \text{VIP}_I^2(j), \quad E_F(j) = \text{VIP}_F^2(j)ET​(j)=VIPT2​(j),EI​(j)=VIPI2​(j),EF​(j)=VIPF2​(j)

Expand:

ET(j)=p⋅∑h=1kSSYh⋅ωT,h(j)Ωh∑h=1kSSYhE_T(j) = p \cdot \frac{\sum_{h=1}^k \text{SSY}_h \cdot \frac{\omega_{T,h}(j)}{\Omega_h}}{\sum_{h=1}^k \text{SSY}_h}ET​(j)=p⋅∑h=1k​SSYh​∑h=1k​SSYh​⋅Ωh​ωT,h​(j)​​

Similarly for EI(j)E_I(j)EI​(j) and EF(j)E_F(j)EF​(j).

Sum:

ET(j)+EI(j)+EF(j)=p⋅∑h=1kSSYh⋅ωT,h(j)+ωI,h(j)+ωF,h(j)Ωh∑h=1kSSYhE_T(j) + E_I(j) + E_F(j) = p \cdot \frac{\sum_{h=1}^k \text{SSY}_h \cdot \frac{\omega_{T,h}(j) + \omega_{I,h}(j) + \omega_{F,h}(j)}{\Omega_h}}{\sum_{h=1}^k \text{SSY}_h}ET​(j)+EI​(j)+EF​(j)=p⋅∑h=1k​SSYh​∑h=1k​SSYh​⋅Ωh​ωT,h​(j)+ωI,h​(j)+ωF,h​(j)​​

By definition of VIPagg\text{VIP}_{\text{agg}}VIPagg​:

ET(j)+EI(j)+EF(j)=VIPagg2(j)E_T(j) + E_I(j) + E_F(j) = \text{VIP}_{\text{agg}}^2(j)ET​(j)+EI​(j)+EF​(j)=VIPagg2​(j)

Therefore:

VIPagg2(j)=VIPT2(j)+VIPI2(j)+VIPF2(j)□\text{VIP}_{\text{agg}}^2(j) = \text{VIP}_T^2(j) + \text{VIP}_I^2(j) + \text{VIP}_F^2(j) \quad \squareVIPagg2​(j)=VIPT2​(j)+VIPI2​(j)+VIPF2​(j)□

5. Corollary: Energy Conservation

∑j=1pVIPagg2(j)=p\sum_{j=1}^p \text{VIP}_{\text{agg}}^2(j) = pj=1∑p​VIPagg2​(j)=p

and:

∑j=1pET(j)+∑j=1pEI(j)+∑j=1pEF(j)=p\sum_{j=1}^p E_T(j) + \sum_{j=1}^p E_I(j) + \sum_{j=1}^p E_F(j) = pj=1∑p​ET​(j)+j=1∑p​EI​(j)+j=1∑p​EF​(j)=p

Interpretation

6. Channel Energies

  • ET(j)E_T(j)ET​(j): Importance of baseline (Truth) for ion jjj
  • EI(j)E_I(j)EI​(j): Importance of uncertainty (Indeterminacy) for ion jjj
  • EF(j)E_F(j)EF​(j): Importance of perturbation (Falsity) for ion jjj

Perturbation energy:

EP(j)=EI(j)+EF(j)E_P(j) = E_I(j) + E_F(j)EP​(j)=EI​(j)+EF​(j)

7. Variable Selection

Use VIPagg(j)\text{VIP}_{\text{agg}}(j)VIPagg​(j) for overall importance:

  • VIPagg(j)≥1\text{VIP}_{\text{agg}}(j) \geq 1VIPagg​(j)≥1: Ion jjj is important for prediction
  • VIPagg(j)<1\text{VIP}_{\text{agg}}(j) < 1VIPagg​(j)<1: Ion jjj is less important

Rationale: Threshold of 1 comes from the conservation property ∑jVIP2=p\sum_j \text{VIP}^2 = p∑j​VIP2=p. If all ions equally important, each would have VIP=1\text{VIP} = 1VIP=1.

8. Attribution Fractions

For ion jjj, baseline fraction:

πG(j)=ET(j)ET(j)+EP(j)∈[0,1]\pi_G(j) = \frac{E_T(j)}{E_T(j) + E_P(j)} \in [0, 1]πG​(j)=ET​(j)+EP​(j)ET​(j)​∈[0,1]

Perturbation fraction:

πA(j)=1−πG(j)=EP(j)ET(j)+EP(j)\pi_A(j) = 1 - \pi_G(j) = \frac{E_P(j)}{E_T(j) + E_P(j)}πA​(j)=1−πG​(j)=ET​(j)+EP​(j)EP​(j)​

See Attribution for detailed discussion.

Algorithm

Input

From fitted PNPLS model:

  • Weight matrix W∈R3p×kW \in \mathbb{R}^{3p \times k}W∈R3p×k
  • Score matrix T∈Rn×kT \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times k}T∈Rn×k
  • Response loadings q∈Rkq \in \mathbb{R}^kq∈Rk

Computation 

# 1. Partition weights by channel
W_T = W[:p, :]      # (p, k)
W_I = W[p:2p, :]    # (p, k)
W_F = W[2p:, :]     # (p, k)

# 2. Squared weights
omega_T = W_T ** 2  # (p, k)
omega_I = W_I ** 2  # (p, k)
omega_F = W_F ** 2  # (p, k)

# 3. Total squared weight per component
Omega = np.sum(W ** 2, axis=0)  # (k,)

# 4. Response energy per component
t_sq = np.sum(T ** 2, axis=0)  # (k,)
SSY = q ** 2 * t_sq            # (k,)
total_SSY = np.sum(SSY)

# 5. Weighted ratio
weight_ratio = SSY / (Omega + eps)  # (k,)

# 6. Energies
E_T = p * (omega_T @ weight_ratio) / total_SSY  # (p,)
E_I = p * (omega_I @ weight_ratio) / total_SSY  # (p,)
E_F = p * (omega_F @ weight_ratio) / total_SSY  # (p,)

# 7. VIPs
VIP_T = np.sqrt(np.maximum(E_T, 0))
VIP_I = np.sqrt(np.maximum(E_I, 0))
VIP_F = np.sqrt(np.maximum(E_F, 0))
VIP_agg = np.sqrt(E_T + E_I + E_F)

Properties

9. Non-Negativity

VIPc(j)≥0∀j,c∈{T,I,F,agg}\text{VIP}_c(j) \geq 0 \quad \forall j, c \in \{T, I, F, \text{agg}\}VIPc​(j)≥0∀j,c∈{T,I,F,agg}

Proof: Squared weights ωc,h(j)≥0\omega_{c,h}(j) \geq 0ωc,h​(j)≥0 and SSYh≥0_h \geq 0h​≥0.

10. Scale Invariance

If variables are standardized, VIP is dimensionless and comparable across ions.

11. Component Monotonicity

Adding more components (increasing kkk) generally:

  • Increases VIPagg\text{VIP}_{\text{agg}}VIPagg​ (more variance explained)
  • May shift balance among VIPT,VIPI,VIPF\text{VIP}_T, \text{VIP}_I, \text{VIP}_FVIPT​,VIPI​,VIPF​

Implication: Use same kkk when comparing across analyses.

Bootstrap Confidence Intervals

12. Procedure

  1. Generate BBB bootstrap samples (resampling with replacement)
  2. For each bootstrap sample b=1,…,Bb = 1, \ldots, Bb=1,…,B:
    • Fit PNPLS
    • Compute NVIP
    • Store VIPT(b),VIPI(b),VIPF(b),VIPagg(b)\text{VIP}^{(b)}_T, \text{VIP}^{(b)}_I, \text{VIP}^{(b)}_F, \text{VIP}^{(b)}_{\text{agg}}VIPT(b)​,VIPI(b)​,VIPF(b)​,VIPagg(b)​
  3. Compute statistics:
    • Mean: VIPˉc=1B∑bVIPc(b)\bar{\text{VIP}}_c = \frac{1}{B} \sum_b \text{VIP}^{(b)}_cVIPˉc​=B1​∑b​VIPc(b)​
    • Std: sd(VIPc)=1B−1∑b(VIPc(b)−VIPˉc)2\text{sd}(\text{VIP}_c) = \sqrt{\frac{1}{B-1} \sum_b (\text{VIP}^{(b)}_c - \bar{\text{VIP}}_c)^2}sd(VIPc​)=B−11​∑b​(VIPc(b)​−VIPˉc​)2​
    • 95% CI: [percentile2.5,percentile97.5][\text{percentile}_{2.5}, \text{percentile}_{97.5}][percentile2.5​,percentile97.5​]

13. Interpretation of Uncertainty

  • Wide CI: Variable importance is unstable across resamples
    • May indicate: overfitting, insufficient data, high noise
  • Narrow CI: Variable importance is stable
    • Reliable ranking

Use: Rank variables by mean VIP; use CI to assess uncertainty.

Diagnostics

14. Verification of L2 Decomposition

After computing NVIP, always verify:

∣VIPagg2(j)−[VIPT2(j)+VIPI2(j)+VIPF2(j)]∣<ϵ|\text{VIP}_{\text{agg}}^2(j) - [\text{VIP}_T^2(j) + \text{VIP}_I^2(j) + \text{VIP}_F^2(j)]| < \epsilon∣VIPagg2​(j)−[VIPT2​(j)+VIPI2​(j)+VIPF2​(j)]∣<ϵ

for all jjj, where ϵ=10−10\epsilon = 10^{-10}ϵ=10−10 (numerical tolerance).

If violated: Implementation error (should never happen with correct code).

from neutrohydro.nvip import verify_l2_decomposition

assert verify_l2_decomposition(nvip_result, tol=1e-10)

15. Component Energy Distribution

Plot SSYh_hh​ vs. hhh:

  • Steep drop: First few components dominate
  • Gradual decline: Many components contribute

Heuristic: If SSY1≫_1 \gg1​≫ SSY2≫…_2 \gg \ldots2​≫…, few components suffice.

16. Channel Dominance

For each ion, classify:

  • Truth-dominant: ET(j)>EI(j)+EF(j)E_T(j) > E_I(j) + E_F(j)ET​(j)>EI​(j)+EF​(j)
  • Perturbation-dominant: ET(j)<EI(j)+EF(j)E_T(j) < E_I(j) + E_F(j)ET​(j)<EI​(j)+EF​(j)

Plot histogram of πG(j)=ET(j)ET(j)+EP(j)\pi_G(j) = \frac{E_T(j)}{E_T(j) + E_P(j)}πG​(j)=ET​(j)+EP​(j)ET​(j)​:

  • Unimodal near 0: Most ions perturbation-driven
  • Unimodal near 1: Most ions baseline-driven
  • Bimodal: Mixed population

Visualization

17. Stacked Bar Plot

For each ion jjj, plot stacked bars:

  • Bottom: ET(j)E_T(j)ET​(j) (Truth, blue)
  • Middle: EI(j)E_I(j)EI​(j) (Indeterminacy, orange)
  • Top: EF(j)E_F(j)EF​(j) (Falsity, red)

Height = VIPagg2(j)\text{VIP}_{\text{agg}}^2(j)VIPagg2​(j)

Horizontal line at y=1y = 1y=1 marks importance threshold.

18. Scatter Plot: πG\pi_GπG​ vs. VIPagg\text{VIP}_{\text{agg}}VIPagg​

Each ion is a point (x,y)=(πG(j),VIPagg(j))(x, y) = (\pi_G(j), \text{VIP}_{\text{agg}}(j))(x,y)=(πG​(j),VIPagg​(j)):

  • Upper left (πG≈0,VIP>1\pi_G \approx 0, \text{VIP} > 1πG​≈0,VIP>1): Important, perturbation-driven
  • Upper right (πG≈1,VIP>1\pi_G \approx 1, \text{VIP} > 1πG​≈1,VIP>1): Important, baseline-driven
  • Lower (VIP<1\text{VIP} < 1VIP<1): Less important

Quadrants:

  • Q1 (πG>0.5,VIP>1\pi_G > 0.5, \text{VIP} > 1πG​>0.5,VIP>1): Important baseline ions
  • Q2 (πG<0.5,VIP>1\pi_G < 0.5, \text{VIP} > 1πG​<0.5,VIP>1): Important perturbation ions

19. Heatmap: Channel VIPs

Heatmap with:

  • Rows: Ions
  • Columns: VIPT,VIPI,VIPF,VIPagg\text{VIP}_T, \text{VIP}_I, \text{VIP}_F, \text{VIP}_{\text{agg}}VIPT​,VIPI​,VIPF​,VIPagg​
  • Color: VIP magnitude

Sort rows by VIPagg\text{VIP}_{\text{agg}}VIPagg​ (descending) to highlight most important ions.

Usage Example 

from neutrohydro import PNPLS, compute_nvip, verify_l2_decomposition
from neutrohydro.nvip import nvip_to_dataframe

# Fit model
model = PNPLS(n_components=5)
model.fit(triplets, y_std)

# Compute NVIP
nvip = compute_nvip(model)

# Verify L2 decomposition
assert verify_l2_decomposition(nvip)

# Identify important ions
important = nvip.VIP_agg >= 1
print(f"Important ions: {np.where(important)[0]}")

# Convert to DataFrame
df = nvip_to_dataframe(nvip, feature_names=ion_names)
print(df.sort_values('VIP_agg', ascending=False))

# Plot stacked VIP energies
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.bar(range(p), nvip.E_T, label='Truth')
ax.bar(range(p), nvip.E_I, bottom=nvip.E_T, label='Indeterminacy')
ax.bar(range(p), nvip.E_F, bottom=nvip.E_T + nvip.E_I, label='Falsity')
ax.axhline(1, color='k', linestyle='--', label='Threshold')
ax.set_xlabel('Ion')
ax.set_ylabel('VIP² Energy')
ax.legend()
plt.show()

Next: Attribution Metrics - NSR, πGπ_GπG​, and sample-level baseline fractions.

\newpage

Attribution Metrics: NSR and Baseline Fractions

Module: neutrohydro.attribution

Overview

Attribution metrics quantify the baseline vs. perturbation character of ions and samples based on NVIP energies. Two levels of attribution:

  1. Ion-level: NSR and π_G quantify baseline fraction per ion
  2. Sample-level: G_i quantifies baseline fraction per water sample

Mathematical Foundation

1. Ion-Level Attribution

1.1 Energy Partition

From NVIP (see nvip.md):

Truth energy (baseline):
ET(j)=VIPT2(j)E_T(j) = \text{VIP}_T^2(j)ET​(j)=VIPT2​(j)

Perturbation energy:
EP(j)=EI(j)+EF(j)=VIPI2(j)+VIPF2(j)E_P(j) = E_I(j) + E_F(j) = \text{VIP}_I^2(j) + \text{VIP}_F^2(j)EP​(j)=EI​(j)+EF​(j)=VIPI2​(j)+VIPF2​(j)

1.2 Baseline Fraction π_G

πG(j)=ET(j)ET(j)+EP(j)∈[0,1]\boxed{\pi_G(j) = \frac{E_T(j)}{E_T(j) + E_P(j)} \in [0, 1]}πG​(j)=ET​(j)+EP​(j)ET​(j)​∈[0,1]​

Interpretation:

  • πG(j)≈1\pi_G(j) \approx 1πG​(j)≈1: Ion jjj prediction driven by baseline
  • πG(j)≈0\pi_G(j) \approx 0πG​(j)≈0: Ion jjj prediction driven by perturbation
  • πG(j)≈0.5\pi_G(j) \approx 0.5πG​(j)≈0.5: Mixed contribution

Perturbation fraction:
πA(j)=1−πG(j)=EP(j)ET(j)+EP(j)\pi_A(j) = 1 - \pi_G(j) = \frac{E_P(j)}{E_T(j) + E_P(j)}πA​(j)=1−πG​(j)=ET​(j)+EP​(j)EP​(j)​

Conservation:
πG(j)+πA(j)=1\pi_G(j) + \pi_A(j) = 1πG​(j)+πA​(j)=1

1.3 Neutrosophic Source Ratio (NSR)

NSR(j)=ET(j)+ϵEP(j)+ϵ\boxed{\text{NSR}(j) = \frac{E_T(j) + \epsilon}{E_P(j) + \epsilon}}NSR(j)=EP​(j)+ϵET​(j)+ϵ​​

where ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 (default: 10−1010^{-10}10−10) prevents division by zero.

Interpretation:

  • NSR(j)≫1(j) \gg 1(j)≫1: Baseline-dominant
  • NSR(j)≈1(j) \approx 1(j)≈1: Balanced
  • NSR(j)≪1(j) \ll 1(j)≪1: Perturbation-dominant

Relationship to π_G:

πG(j)=NSR(j)1+NSR(j)\pi_G(j) = \frac{\text{NSR}(j)}{1 + \text{NSR}(j)}πG​(j)=1+NSR(j)NSR(j)​

NSR(j)=πG(j)1−πG(j)\text{NSR}(j) = \frac{\pi_G(j)}{1 - \pi_G(j)}NSR(j)=1−πG​(j)πG​(j)​

NSR is the odds ratio version of the fraction π_G.

1.4 Classification

Choose threshold γ∈(0.5,1)\gamma \in (0.5, 1)γ∈(0.5,1) (default: γ=0.7\gamma = 0.7γ=0.7):

  • Baseline-dominant: πG(j)≥γ\pi_G(j) \geq \gammaπG​(j)≥γ
  • Perturbation-dominant: πG(j)≤1−γ\pi_G(j) \leq 1 - \gammaπG​(j)≤1−γ
  • Mixed: 1−γ<πG(j)<γ1 - \gamma < \pi_G(j) < \gamma1−γ<πG​(j)<γ

Rationale for γ = 0.7:

  • Corresponds to NSR ≈2.33\approx 2.33≈2.33 (odds of 2.33:1)
  • Strong but not extreme threshold
  • Balances sensitivity and specificity

2. Sample-Level Attribution

2.1 Net Contributions

For sample iii, ion jjj, the net contribution to prediction is:

cij=(X~T)ijβT(j)+(X~I)ijβI(j)+(X~F)ijβF(j)c_{ij} = (\widetilde{X}_T)_{ij} \beta_T(j) + (\widetilde{X}_I)_{ij} \beta_I(j) + (\widetilde{X}_F)_{ij} \beta_F(j)cij​=(XT​)ij​βT​(j)+(XI​)ij​βI​(j)+(XF​)ij​βF​(j)

where:

  • X~T,X~I,X~F\widetilde{X}_T, \widetilde{X}_I, \widetilde{X}_FXT​,XI​,XF​ are weighted channel matrices
  • βT,βI,βF\beta_T, \beta_I, \beta_FβT​,βI​,βF​ are regression coefficients partitioned by channel

2.2 Attribution Mass

To avoid sign cancellation, use absolute contributions:

wij=∣cij∣w_{ij} = |c_{ij}|wij​=∣cij​∣

Interpretation: wijw_{ij}wij​ quantifies how much ion jjj contributes (in magnitude) to predicting sample iii.

2.3 Sample Baseline Fraction G_i

Gi=∑j=1pπG(j)⋅wij∑j=1pwij∈[0,1]\boxed{G_i = \frac{\sum_{j=1}^p \pi_G(j) \cdot w_{ij}}{\sum_{j=1}^p w_{ij}} \in [0, 1]}Gi​=∑j=1p​wij​∑j=1p​πG​(j)⋅wij​​∈[0,1]​

Weighted average of ion-level baseline fractions, using attribution masses as weights.

Interpretation:

  • Gi≈1G_i \approx 1Gi​≈1: Sample iii prediction driven by baseline-dominant ions
  • Gi≈0G_i \approx 0Gi​≈0: Sample iii prediction driven by perturbation-dominant ions
  • Gi≈0.5G_i \approx 0.5Gi​≈0.5: Mixed

Sample perturbation fraction:
Ai=1−GiA_i = 1 - G_iAi​=1−Gi​

Conservation:
Gi+Ai=1G_i + A_i = 1Gi​+Ai​=1

2.4 Precise Interpretation

GiG_iGi​ is not the fraction of mass in baseline sources. Rather:

GiG_iGi​ is the fraction of the model's absolute predictive attribution mass carried by baseline-dominant ions.

Physical interpretation of baseline vs. perturbation requires external validation (see Section 5).

3. Algorithm

Ion-Level

Input: NVIP result (ET,EI,EF)(E_T, E_I, E_F)(ET​,EI​,EF​), threshold γ\gammaγ, epsilon ϵ\epsilonϵ

Output: NSR, πGπ_GπG​, πAπ_AπA​, classification

# Perturbation energy
E_P = E_I + E_F

# NSR (odds ratio)
NSR = (E_T + epsilon) / (E_P + epsilon)

# Baseline fraction
total_energy = E_T + E_P
pi_G = np.where(total_energy > epsilon, E_T / total_energy, 0.5)
pi_G = np.clip(pi_G, 0.0, 1.0)

# Perturbation fraction
pi_A = 1.0 - pi_G

# Classification
classification = np.empty(p, dtype='U12')
classification[:] = "mixed"
classification[pi_G >= gamma] = "baseline"
classification[pi_G <= 1 - gamma] = "perturbation"

Sample-Level

Input: Fitted model (coefficients), triplet data, NSR result (πGπ_GπG​)

Output: G, A, attribution masses w, contributions c

# Get coefficients by channel
beta_T, beta_I, beta_F = get_coefficients_by_channel(model)

# Weighted data
W_precision = np.exp(-lambda_F * triplets.F)
X_T_w = W_precision * triplets.T
X_I_w = W_precision * sqrt(rho_I) * triplets.I
X_F_w = W_precision * sqrt(rho_F) * triplets.F

# Net contributions
c = X_T_w * beta_T + X_I_w * beta_I + X_F_w * beta_F  # (n, p)

# Attribution mass
w = np.abs(c)

# Sample baseline fraction
numerator = w @ pi_G          # (n,)
denominator = w.sum(axis=1)   # (n,)
G = np.where(denominator > eps, numerator / denominator, 0.5)
G = np.clip(G, 0.0, 1.0)

# Sample perturbation fraction
A = 1.0 - G

4. Properties

4.1 Bounds

  1. πG(j),πA(j)∈[0,1]\pi_G(j), \pi_A(j) \in [0, 1]πG​(j),πA​(j)∈[0,1] for all jjj
  2. Gi,Ai∈[0,1]G_i, A_i \in [0, 1]Gi​,Ai​∈[0,1] for all iii
  3. NSR(j)∈[0,∞](j) \in [0, \infty](j)∈[0,∞]

4.2 Conservation

  1. πG(j)+πA(j)=1\pi_G(j) + \pi_A(j) = 1πG​(j)+πA​(j)=1 for all jjj
  2. Gi+Ai=1G_i + A_i = 1Gi​+Ai​=1 for all iii

Proof of Ion-Level Conservation

Theorem: πG(j)+πA(j)=1\pi_G(j) + \pi_A(j) = 1πG​(j)+πA​(j)=1 for all ions jjj.

Proof:

By definition (Section 1.2):
πG(j)=ET(j)ET(j)+EP(j)\pi_G(j) = \frac{E_T(j)}{E_T(j) + E_P(j)}πG​(j)=ET​(j)+EP​(j)ET​(j)​

πA(j)=EP(j)ET(j)+EP(j)\pi_A(j) = \frac{E_P(j)}{E_T(j) + E_P(j)}πA​(j)=ET​(j)+EP​(j)EP​(j)​

Sum:
πG(j)+πA(j)=ET(j)ET(j)+EP(j)+EP(j)ET(j)+EP(j)\pi_G(j) + \pi_A(j) = \frac{E_T(j)}{E_T(j) + E_P(j)} + \frac{E_P(j)}{E_T(j) + E_P(j)}πG​(j)+πA​(j)=ET​(j)+EP​(j)ET​(j)​+ET​(j)+EP​(j)EP​(j)​

=ET(j)+EP(j)ET(j)+EP(j)=1= \frac{E_T(j) + E_P(j)}{E_T(j) + E_P(j)} = 1=ET​(j)+EP​(j)ET​(j)+EP​(j)​=1

□\square□

Note: This holds even when ET(j)+EP(j)=0E_T(j) + E_P(j) = 0ET​(j)+EP​(j)=0 by the convention πG(j)=0.5\pi_G(j) = 0.5πG​(j)=0.5 in this degenerate case (see algorithm).

Proof of Sample-Level Conservation

Theorem: Gi+Ai=1G_i + A_i = 1Gi​+Ai​=1 for all samples iii.

Proof:

By definition (Section 2.3):
Gi=∑j=1pπG(j)⋅wij∑j=1pwijG_i = \frac{\sum_{j=1}^p \pi_G(j) \cdot w_{ij}}{\sum_{j=1}^p w_{ij}}Gi​=∑j=1p​wij​∑j=1p​πG​(j)⋅wij​​

where wij=∣cij∣w_{ij} = |c_{ij}|wij​=∣cij​∣ are attribution masses.

By definition of AiA_iAi​:
Ai=1−GiA_i = 1 - G_iAi​=1−Gi​

Substituting:
Ai=1−∑j=1pπG(j)⋅wij∑j=1pwijA_i = 1 - \frac{\sum_{j=1}^p \pi_G(j) \cdot w_{ij}}{\sum_{j=1}^p w_{ij}}Ai​=1−∑j=1p​wij​∑j=1p​πG​(j)⋅wij​​

=∑j=1pwij−∑j=1pπG(j)⋅wij∑j=1pwij= \frac{\sum_{j=1}^p w_{ij} - \sum_{j=1}^p \pi_G(j) \cdot w_{ij}}{\sum_{j=1}^p w_{ij}}=∑j=1p​wij​∑j=1p​wij​−∑j=1p​πG​(j)⋅wij​​

=∑j=1pwij(1−πG(j))∑j=1pwij= \frac{\sum_{j=1}^p w_{ij}(1 - \pi_G(j))}{\sum_{j=1}^p w_{ij}}=∑j=1p​wij​∑j=1p​wij​(1−πG​(j))​

Using ion-level conservation 1−πG(j)=πA(j)1 - \pi_G(j) = \pi_A(j)1−πG​(j)=πA​(j):
Ai=∑j=1pwij⋅πA(j)∑j=1pwijA_i = \frac{\sum_{j=1}^p w_{ij} \cdot \pi_A(j)}{\sum_{j=1}^p w_{ij}}Ai​=∑j=1p​wij​∑j=1p​wij​⋅πA​(j)​

This is the weighted average of perturbation fractions, so:
Gi+Ai=∑j=1pwij(πG(j)+πA(j))∑j=1pwij=∑j=1pwij∑j=1pwij=1G_i + A_i = \frac{\sum_{j=1}^p w_{ij}(\pi_G(j) + \pi_A(j))}{\sum_{j=1}^p w_{ij}} = \frac{\sum_{j=1}^p w_{ij}}{\sum_{j=1}^p w_{ij}} = 1Gi​+Ai​=∑j=1p​wij​∑j=1p​wij​(πG​(j)+πA​(j))​=∑j=1p​wij​∑j=1p​wij​​=1

□\square□

4.3 Monotonicity

If ET(j)E_T(j)ET​(j) increases (holding EP(j)E_P(j)EP​(j) fixed), then:

  • πG(j)\pi_G(j)πG​(j) increases
  • NSR(j)(j)(j) increases
  • Classification may change to "baseline"

4.4 Extremes

All baseline (EP(j)=0E_P(j) = 0EP​(j)=0):

  • πG(j)=1\pi_G(j) = 1πG​(j)=1
  • NSR(j)→∞(j) \to \infty(j)→∞

All perturbation (ET(j)=0E_T(j) = 0ET​(j)=0):

  • πG(j)=0\pi_G(j) = 0πG​(j)=0
  • NSR(j)=0(j) = 0(j)=0

Equal (ET(j)=EP(j)E_T(j) = E_P(j)ET​(j)=EP​(j)):

  • πG(j)=0.5\pi_G(j) = 0.5πG​(j)=0.5
  • NSR(j)=1(j) = 1(j)=1

5. Interpretation and Validation

5.1 Operational Definition

π_G and G are mathematically well-defined operational quantities. However, interpreting them as physical source fractions (e.g., geogenic vs. anthropogenic) requires:

  1. External evidence:

    • Spatial patterns (urban vs. rural)
    • Temporal trends (pre/post contamination)
    • Isotopic tracers
    • Land use correlations

  2. Baseline validation:

    • Does the chosen baseline operator (median, low-rank, etc.) capture the "natural" state?
    • Are perturbations truly anomalies, not natural variability?

  3. Domain expertise:

    • Hydrogeological context
    • Known contamination sources
    • Historical water quality data

5.2 Common Pitfalls

Pitfall 1: Assuming πGπ_GπG​ = fraction of mass from geogenic sources

Reality: πGπ_GπG​ quantifies contribution to prediction importance, not mass balance.

Pitfall 2: Ignoring baseline choice

Reality: Different baseline operators (median vs. low-rank) yield different πGπ_GπG​.

Pitfall 3: Treating classification as hard truth

Reality: Threshold γγγ is somewhat arbitrary; use as guide, not absolute.

5.3 Recommended Workflow

  1. Compute πGπ_GπG​ and G with multiple baseline types (median, low-rank)
  2. Check robustness: Do classifications agree?
  3. Cross-validate with external data:
    • Do "baseline-dominant" samples cluster spatially in pristine areas?
    • Do "perturbation-dominant" samples correspond to known contamination?
  4. Sensitivity analysis: Vary γγγ; check if rankings change drastically

6. Summary Statistics

6.1 Ion-Level Summary

For a dataset:

  • Mean πGπ_GπG​: Average baseline fraction across all ions
  • N baseline: Number of baseline-dominant ions
  • N perturbation: Number of perturbation-dominant ions
  • N mixed: Number of mixed ions
  • Most baseline ion: arg maxj_jj​ πG(j)π_G(j)πG​(j)
  • Most perturbation ion: arg minj_jj​ πG(j)π_G(j)πG​(j)

6.2 Sample-Level Summary

  • Mean G: Average baseline fraction across all samples
  • Std G: Variability in baseline character
  • Frac baseline samples: Fraction with G≥γG \geq \gammaG≥γ
  • Frac perturbation samples: Fraction with G≤1−γG \leq 1 - \gammaG≤1−γ

  Mixed samples: 37 (37%)

8. Usage Example 

from neutrohydro import compute_nvip, compute_nsr, compute_sample_baseline_fraction
from neutrohydro.attribution import attribution_summary, nsr_to_dataframe

# After fitting model
nvip = compute_nvip(model)

# Ion-level attribution
nsr = compute_nsr(nvip, epsilon=1e-10, gamma=0.7)

print(f"Baseline ions: {sum(nsr.classification == 'baseline')}")
print(f"Perturbation ions: {sum(nsr.classification == 'perturbation')}")

# Sample-level attribution
sample_attr = compute_sample_baseline_fraction(model, triplets, nsr)

print(f"Mean G: {sample_attr.G.mean():.3f}")
print(f"Std G: {sample_attr.G.std():.3f}")

# Summary statistics
summary = attribution_summary(nsr, sample_attr, ion_names)
print(summary)

# DataFrame export
df_nsr = nsr_to_dataframe(nsr, ion_names)
print(df_nsr.sort_values('pi_G', ascending=False))

Baseline type High Test multiple; check robustness

ρF\rho_FρF​ Medium (changes EFE_FEF​ weight) Default 1.0 unless strong prior
λF\lambda_FλF​ Low (affects weights, not VIP) Default 1.0
kkk (components) Medium (more components → finer decomposition) Cross-validate

10. Comparison to Other Methods

Method Outputs Interpretation Limitations
NVIP/NSR πGπ_GπG​ per ion, G per sample Baseline vs. perturbation fraction Requires validation for physical meaning
PMF Source contributions Mass apportionment Compositional, non-negative
PCA loadings Variable weights Pattern strength Not directly about sources
APCS Source contributions Absolute mass Requires source profiles

Advantages of NSR:

  • Non-compositional: Works in absolute space
  • Explicit uncertainty: I channel captures ambiguity
  • L2 decomposition: Unambiguous partitioning
